I will follow the main issues (ummahāt masā’il) of each chapter and establish them with the general ruling in their outward name, then move to the ruling of that very issue in the inward being, until I finish it. Allah supports and assists.

### Clarification and Elucidation: Rulings of Purification

The first matter is naming it purification (al-ṭahāra), which we have discussed at the beginning of the chapter, outwardly and inwardly. We shall now proceed, if Allah wills, to its rulings (aḥkām): looking at its obligation (wujūb), upon whom it is obligatory, when it is obligatory, its acts, the means by which it is performed, its nullifiers (nawāqiḍ), and the description of the things for which it is performed, just as the scholars of the Law have done and established in their books. The matter of purification is confined to this. We shall examine this outwardly and inwardly.

We shall only allude to the outward rulings so that the reader does not need to refer to the books of the jurists (fuqahā’), and what we mention will suffice him. We will not address the proofs (adillāh) used by the scholars to establish these rulings—whether from the Book, the Sunna, consensus (Ijmā’), or analogy (Qiyās) according to those who accept it, based on finding a common effective cause (‘illa jāmi’a) between the textually mentioned and the unmentioned—nor will I address the principles of jurisprudence (uṣūl al-fiqh) or the proofs, since the common people are not tasked with examining the proof. We will mention the main subsidiary rulings (ummahāt furū’ al-aḥkām) and the views of people regarding them, concerning obligation and non-obligation.

### Connection: The Obligation of Purification, Upon Whom it is Obligatory, and When

First, we say that all Muslims unanimously agree, without dissent, on the obligation of purification upon everyone for whom prayer is due when its time enters, and that it is obligatory upon the pubescent, sane person. People disagreed on whether Islam is a condition for its obligation or not. This is the ruling of the outward.

As for the inward ruling, which is inward purification (al-ṭahāra al-bāṭina), we say that the inward essence and spirit of prayer is intimate communion (munājāt) with the Real (al-Ḥaqq), as He said: <<قسمت الصلاة بيني وبين عبدي نصفين>> (I have divided the prayer between Myself and My servant into two halves).

The Hadith mentions the servant saying such-and-such, and Allah saying such-and-such. Whenever the servant intends to commune with his Lord in any act, the purification of his heart from everything that distracts him from communing with his Lord in that act becomes necessary for him. If he is not characterized by this purification at the time of his communion, then he has not communed with Him, and he has behaved improperly, making him more deserving of expulsion. I shall mention the divisions of this purification in the ruling when discussing its acts, if Allah wills.

### Purification in the Heart and in the Limbs

As for the scholars’ saying that it is obligatory upon the pubescent, sane person by consensus, and their disagreement regarding Islam, likewise, in our view, this purification is obligatory upon the rational person (‘āqil)—the one who understands Allah’s command and prohibition, what Allah casts into his inner secret (sirr), and who distinguishes between the thoughts (khawāṭir) of his heart: what is from Allah, what is from his self (nafs), what is from the angel’s suggestion (lammat al-malak), or what is from the devil’s suggestion (lammat al-shayṭān). That is the [Perfect] Human (al-Insān).

When he reaches this level of gnosis (ma’rifa) and discernment, and understands what Allah wants from him, and hears the saying of Allah the Exalted: <<وسعني قلب عبدي>> (The heart of My servant contains Me), it becomes obligatory upon him at that point to apply this purification to his heart and to every limb related to it, according to the legislated limit.

For example, the purification of the sight (al-baṣar) inwardly is to look at things with contemplation (‘ibra) and insight, and not to send one’s gaze aimlessly. Such a state is only achieved by one who has realized the application of the legislated purification in all its proper places. Allah the Exalted says: <<إِنَّ فِي ذَلِكَ لَعِبْرَةً لِأُولِي الْأَبْصَارِ>> (Indeed in that is a lesson for those who have vision) [Q. 3:13]. He attributed it to the eyes (al-abṣār), but contemplation is for the insights (al-baṣā’ir). He mentioned the eyes because they are the means leading to the inward, where the very essence of insight contemplates. And so it is for all the limbs.

### Are Non-Believers Addressed by the Subsidiary Rulings of the Law?

As for the scholars’ saying regarding this purification—whether Islam is a condition for its obligation—it is equivalent to their question: Are non-believers (al-kuffār) addressed by the subsidiary rulings (furū’) of the Law? And whether the hypocrite (al-munāfiq), if he performs ablution, has fulfilled an obligation or not? This is a disputed issue that encompasses all legislated rulings.

Our school of thought is that all people universally—believer, non-believer, and hypocrite—are responsible and addressed by the fundamentals (uṣūl) and the subsidiaries (furū’) of the Law, and they will be held accountable on the Day of Resurrection for both the fundamentals and the subsidiaries.

For this reason, the hypocrite will be in the lowest depth (al-dark al-asfal) of the Fire, which is the inward core of the Fire. The hypocrite is punished by the Fire <<الَّتِي تَطَّلِعُ عَلَى الْأَفْئِدَةِ>> (which ascends to the hearts) [Q. 104:7], because in this world he performed the outward form of the legislated ruling—uttering the testimony (Shahāda), showing confirmation of the messengers, and performing outward acts—but they did not possess an atom’s weight of faith (Iman) in their inward beings. By this measure, they are distinguished from the non-believers, and they are called hypocrites. Allah the Exalted says: <<إِنَّ اللَّهَ جَامِعُ الْمُنَافِقِينَ وَالْكَافِرِينَ فِي جَهَنَّمَ جَمِيعًا>> (Indeed, Allah will gather the hypocrites and disbelievers in Hell all together) [Q. 4:140]. He mentioned the abode. The hypocrites are punished in the lowest part of Hell, while the non-believers have punishment in the upper and lower parts.

### Punishment in Hell is in Levels and Layers

Allah has arranged levels and layers (marātib wa ṭabaqāt) of punishment in the Fire of Hell for specific deeds performed by specific limbs, according to a known measure that is not exceeded.

The Fire has absolutely no access to the locus of the believer’s faith (Iman). Therefore, he has no share in the Fire <<الَّتِي تَطَّلِعُ عَلَى الْأَفْئِدَةِ>> (which ascends to the hearts). Even if [faith] leaves him there, its care remains active in its place in man. It only leaves him to protect him and ward off from him whatever Allah wills of His punishment, just as it leaves him in this world when he commits an act of disobedience.

The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said concerning the believer who drinks wine, steals, or fornicates, that he does none of these things while he is a believer at the time of the act, and he said that faith leaves him at that time, during the act.

People interpreted this Hadith incorrectly because they did not understand the Lawgiver’s intent, and they interpreted faith as actions, saying that he meant the action. But the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, clarified his intent in another Hadith:

He said, peace and blessings be upon him: <<إن العبد إذا زنى خرج عنه الايمان حتى يصير عليه كالظلة فإذا أقلع رجع إليه الايمان>> (When the servant fornicates, faith leaves him until it becomes like a cloud [al-ẓulla] over him. When he stops, faith returns to him).

### Disobedience and Faith Do Not Coexist

Know that the Divine Wisdom (al-Ḥikma al-Ilāhiyya) in this is that when the servant embarks upon the transgression—which he, as a believer, knows to be a transgression and an act of disobedience—he has exposed himself by his action to the descent of Allah’s punishment and the infliction of penalty upon him, and that action calls for the occurrence of affliction from Allah. So his faith leaves his heart until it is like a cloud over him. When the affliction descends from Allah seeking him, his faith meets it and wards it off from him, for nothing can resist faith, and it prevents the affliction from reaching him, as a mercy from Allah. There is no clarification after the clarification of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.

For this reason, we said that the believing servant never performs an act of disobedience that is not mixed with an act of obedience, which is his being a believer who knows it is disobedience. He is among those who <<خَلَطُوا عَمَلًا صَالِحًا وَآخَرَ سَيِّئًا>> (mixed a righteous deed with another evil one) [Q. 9:102]. Allah said: <<عَسَى اللَّهُ أَنْ يَتُوبَ عَلَيْهِمْ>> (Perhaps Allah will turn to them in forgiveness). Repentance (al-Tawba) means returning, so the meaning is that He will return to them with mercy. He completed the verse by saying: <<إِنَّ اللَّهَ غَفُورٌ رَحِيمٌ>> (Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful). Scholars say that *‘asā* (perhaps) from Allah is obligatory, for nothing can prevent Him.

### Faith is the Essence of Inward Purification

Then we return and say that since Faith (al-Iman) is the very essence of inward purification (al-ṭahāra al-bāṭin), the disagreement regarding it cannot be conceived as it is conceived regarding outward purification, except in a subtle way where the ruling of the outward in the inward is the ruling of the inward in the outward purification.

We say, from that perspective: Is the utterance of faith a condition for the validity of inward purification by faith, such that the tongue must articulate what the heart believes? Or not? If he does not manifest what he believes inwardly, he is a hypocrite in the world of the Unseen (Ghayb), like the outward hypocrite in the world of Witnessing (Shahāda). For example, the believer believes in the obligation of prayer but does not pray or purify himself, just as the hypocrite prays and purifies himself but does not believe in its obligation upon him in his heart, nor does he believe in or perform it due to the messenger who legislated it for him. This is the meaning, if you realize the contemplation of it, so that the ruling flows through the outward and the inward in the same form as the disagreement and consensus in the outward. Know this.

(Connection) As for the acts of this purification, they have been mentioned in the Book and the Sunna, clarifying what is obligatory (farḍ), what is Sunna, and what is recommended (mustaḥabb) among its acts. This purification has conditions (shurūṭ), pillars (arkān), descriptions (ṣifāt), numbers, and specific limits in their places.

### Intention is a Condition for the Validity of Purification

Among its conditions is the intention (al-niyya), which is the aim (al-qaṣd) of performing the act as an approach (qurba) to Allah the Exalted at the commencement of the act. Some people hold that it is a condition for the validity of that act, which is not valid without its existence, and what is necessary to achieve an obligation is itself obligatory (wājib), which is our school of thought. We hold this for both outward and inward purification. In our view, it is more emphasized and more obligatory (awkad wa awjab) in the inward, because intention is also an attribute of the inward, so its ruling in inward purification is stronger because it rules in the place of its authority, while the outward is foreign to it. For this reason, there is no disagreement concerning it in our knowledge of the inward, though there is disagreement concerning it in the outward. We have already provided sufficient discussion on intention. Others hold that it is not a condition for validity, and what we mentioned regarding ablution with water suffices.

### Connection: Washing the Hand Before Placing it in the Ablution Vessel

The scholars of the Law disagreed on washing the hand before inserting it into the vessel from which one intends to perform ablution, holding four opinions: Some say washing them is Sunna absolutely. Some say it is recommended for one who doubts the purity of his hand. Some say washing the hand is obligatory upon one rising from sleep before inserting it into the vessel from which he intends to perform ablution. And some say it is obligatory only upon one waking from night sleep specifically. This summarizes the schools of thought in my knowledge regarding this issue. Each proponent has a proof from deduction to support his view, but this book is not the place to cite their proofs.

### Completion: The Ruling on Washing the Hand from the Inward Perspective

The ruling of this issue in the inward is the purification of the hand by abandoning what the Law has tasked it to abandon. This is of two divisions: that which is obligatory (wājib) to abandon, and that which is recommended (mandūb) to abandon. The obligatory and the pillar (farḍ) are synonymous terms for us, referring to a single meaning, so there is no difference for us if you say obligatory or pillar.

### Obligatory Abandonment and Recommended Abandonment

We say: The obligatory abandonment occurs if the hand is upon something concerning which the Law rules that the hand is usurping (ghāṣiba), or that the thing is stolen, or that betrayal (khiyāna) has occurred in it, and everything the Lawgiver has not permitted the hand to dispose of. The distinctions in these situations are clear. It is obligatory to purify the hand from all of this. We shall mention what it is purified by in its proper place, if Allah wills. This purification is obligatory upon it.

As for the recommended purification (al-ṭahāra al-mandūb ilayhā), it is the abandonment of permissible worldly possessions (al-dunyā) that the hand holds, which the Law encourages the hand to relinquish out of desire for what is with Allah. This is asceticism (al-zuhd), and it is a trade, for it has a recompense with Allah for what it abandoned, and abandonment is higher than retention. This is a matter of consensus in every religion and sect, legally and rationally, for people agree that asceticism in the world, abandoning the accumulation of its debris, and relinquishing what one holds of it is preferable to every rational person. This is the recommended purification for the hand, which is the Sunna.

As for the ruling of preferability (istiḥbāb) in the purification of the hand for one who doubts its purity, it is the relinquishing of the wealth in his hand due to a doubt (shubha) that arose concerning its legality. He should not retain it. This is scrupulousness (al-wara’), not asceticism (al-zuhd). Even if it has an aspect of legality, it is preferable to abandon it, for observing sanctity is better. In retaining it, you are accountable, but in abandoning it due to the doubt that arose in you, you are not accountable; rather, you are closer to reward for that. This is more appropriate for the recommended purification, and preferability in abandoning the permissible is better.

### Night is the Unseen and Day is the Witnessed

As for their disagreement regarding the obligation of washing the hand after sleep absolutely, and those who restricted it to night sleep, know that night (al-layl) is the Unseen (Ghayb) because it is the locus of concealment, and thus night was made a covering (libās). Day (al-nahār) is the Witnessed (Shahāda) because it is the locus of appearance and movement, and thus it was made a means of livelihood (ma’āsh) for seeking bounty (al-faḍl)—meaning seeking provision (rizq) from its proper source. The bounty sought in it is increase and honor, which is the increase of virtues. For one gathers what is not his provision, and this is excess (fuḍūl), because he gathers it for his heir or someone else, for a person’s provision is not what he gathers, but what he consumes as nourishment.

Know that the sleeper is undoubtedly in the world of the Unseen. If the sleep is at night, it is Unseen within Unseen (Ghayb fī Ghayb), so its ruling is stronger. Sleep during the day is Unseen within Witnessed (Ghayb fī Shahāda), so its ruling is weaker. Do you not see that He made sleep a rest (subāt)? It is undoubtedly rest, and it is stronger at night, for one is more deeply immersed in it than in day sleep. The Unseen is the origin, so night is the origin, and the Witnessed is the branch, so day is the branch. <<وَآيَةٌ لَهُمُ اللَّيْلُ نَسْلَخُ مِنْهُ النَّهَارَ>> (And a sign for them is the night; We withdraw from it the day) [Q. 36:37]. The day is stripped from the night.

Since night conceals things and does not clarify the realities of their forms to the eyes, it resembles ignorance (al-jahl). Ignorance of a thing does not clarify its ruling. Whoever is ignorant of the Law concerning a thing does not know its ruling regarding it.

### The Sleeper in His Sleep and the Ignorant in His Ignorance

Since the sleeper in his state of sleep knows nothing of the outward affairs in the world of Witnessing concerning people, sleep is pure ignorance, except for the one whose eye sleeps but whose heart does not, like the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and those of his inheritors whom Allah wills in that state.

Since the day clarifies things, reveals the forms of their essences, and makes apparent to the pious what should be avoided of harmful matters and what should not be avoided, it resembles knowledge (‘ilm). Knowledge is what clarifies the ruling of the Law concerning things.

Since the sleeper during the day is characterized by ignorance due to his sleep—for sleep is the opposite of knowledge—he might extend his hand or foot without knowledge and spoil something that he would not have exposed to ruin had he been awake. Therefore, the Law obligated purification upon him by the teacher (al-mu’allim) after the sleep of ignorance when he wakes up, so that he may know the ruling of the Law through his wakefulness. For he did not know, in his state of ignorant sleep, whether his hand had moved into what was permissible for him to possess or what was not permissible for him to possess, such as usurped property and the like, as we mentioned.

The one who disagrees considers the saying, "Where did his hand spend the night?" They both share the state of sleep, but the Lawgiver only mentioned spending the night because most sleep occurs then, and He always considers the majority case. Thus, He made this ruling specific to night sleep. However, considering sleep itself is more appropriate than considering night sleep.

The one who considers night sleep says that when a person sleeps during the day, there might be a person or a group present who, if they see the sleeper moving his hand or foot, prevent him from breaking a jar or something else, or prevent a small nursing child from having his hand placed over his mouth, which might harm him or stop his breathing, leading to death—we have seen this happen. The awake person present prevents this by removing the child or the jar or whatever is near, due to the light of the day that revealed it and his wakefulness. Likewise, the scholar acts toward the ignorant person: if he sees him acting without knowledge of the Law’s ruling concerning it, he alerts him, or the Law intervenes between him and that action.

Therefore, washing the hand is obligatory upon the heedless (al-ghāfil), who is the sleeper during the day, and the ignorant (al-jāhil), who is the sleeper during the night, inwardly, in our view.

As for our consideration of purification before inserting the hand into the vessel, it is because we are addressed by knowledge and action. Knowledge is the water, and action is the washing, and purification is achieved by both. Washing the hand before inserting it into the ablution vessel is the beautiful intention (al-qaṣd al-jamīl) that one establishes in himself regarding that act toward the presence of the Real (Janāb al-Ḥaqq), in which lies his felicity, at the commencement of the act in detail. This is the meaning of washing the hand before inserting it into the ablution vessel in inward purification.

(Connection) Rinsing the Mouth (al-Maḍmaḍa) and Sniffing Water (al-Istinshāq)

The scholars of the Law disagreed on these two acts, holding three opinions: Some say both are Sunna. Some say both are obligatory (farḍ). Some say rinsing the mouth is Sunna and sniffing water is obligatory. This is the ruling concerning them outwardly, as we have transmitted it.

### The Ruling on Maḍmaḍa and Istinshāq Inwardly

As for their ruling inwardly, some parts are obligatory (farḍ) and some are Sunna.

Regarding rinsing the mouth (al-maḍmaḍa), the obligatory part is the utterance of *Lā ilāha illā Allāh* (There is no god but Allah), for by it your tongue and your chest are purified from polytheism (al-shirk), since its letters originate from the chest and the tongue. Likewise, this applies to every obligatory utterance that Allah has commanded you to pronounce, which cannot be performed on your behalf by another person, thereby relieving you of the duty, such as a communal obligation (farḍ al-kifāya). For example, if a man sees a blind person from afar about to fall into a pit that would harm or kill him, it becomes an individual obligation (farḍ al-‘ayn) upon him to call out to warn him of the fall using words he understands, because he cannot reach him. If someone else precedes him in doing so, that obligation is lifted from him. If he speaks it anyway, it is better for him, but not obligatory.

If he rinses his mouth inwardly with this and similar things, he has achieved good and spoken good. Good speech and truthfulness of the tongue are purification from lying and speaking ill openly is purification from <<الْجَهْرَ بِالسُّوءِ مِنَ الْقَوْلِ>> (the public mention of evil) [Q. 4:148], even if the reward is for his saying <<إِلَّا مَنْ ظُلِمَ>> (except one who has been wronged), yet silence concerning it is better. Enjoining good and forbidding evil are purification from their opposites. This is the obligatory part of rinsing the mouth and its Sunna acts.

Likewise is sniffing water (al-istinshāq).

### The Nose in Arab Custom is a Symbol of Honor and Arrogance

Know that the esoteric meaning of sniffing water into the nose (الاستنشاق) is related to the fact that the nose, in Arab custom, is the locus of honor (العزة) and arrogance (الكبرياء). This is why the Arabs say in their supplication, "May Allah rub his nose in the dust (أرغم الله أنفه)." And the phrase, "in spite of his nose (على رغم أنفه)," where *al-raghām* (الرغام) means dust, signifies: "May Allah cast you down from your arrogance (كبريائك) and honor (عزك) to the station of abasement (الذلة) and lowliness (الصغار)." Thus, it is symbolized by dust, for Allah named the earth "submissive" (ذلول) by way of hyperbole, since the most abased of the abased is that which the abased treads upon. Servants (العبيد) are abased, and they tread upon the earth by walking upon its pathways. For this reason, He named it using the intensive form.

### [Blowing the Nose (Al-Istinthār) or the Application of the Rules of Servitude (العبودية)]

This [arrogance] cannot be repelled, nor can inner arrogance (الكبرياء) be removed, except by applying the rules of servitude (العبودية), abasement (الذلة), and neediness (الافتقار). For this reason, the cleansing of the nasal passage (الاستنثار) was legislated alongside sniffing water (الاستنشاق). It is said to the worshipper: "Put water in your nose, then blow it out (استنثر)." The water here is your knowledge (علمك) of your servitude (عبوديتك). When you apply this knowledge in the locus of your arrogance, the arrogance departs from its place, and that is the cleansing (الاستنثار).

Part of this is obligatory (فرض), and its application in the esoteric realm (الباطن) is undoubtedly obligatory. As for it being a recommended practice (سنة), this means that if you omit it, your ablution (وضوؤك) is valid. Its application in this context is like if you neglected to deal with your servant or someone under your command—and here is a subtle secret contained within the phrase "My Lord, grant me such-and-such"—or someone beneath you with humility, and instead displayed honor (العزة) and the rule of authority (الرئاسة) for a benefit you perceive, which the Lawgiver (الشارع) permitted you. If you did not perform the sniffing, the ruling of your purification (طهارتك) is valid without performing this act, even though performing it is superior. This is the point where its obligation (فرضها) falls away. Therefore, we said it may be a recommended practice (سنة) or it may be obligatory (فرضا). This is based on our knowledge that if the people of a city unanimously agreed to abandon a recommended practice, it would be obligatory to fight them, but if a single person abandoned it, he would not be killed. The Prophet (صلى الله عليه وسلم) would not raid a city if he approached it at night until morning. If he heard the call to prayer (أذانا), he would hold back; otherwise, he would raid. If he did not hear the call to prayer, he would recite: <<إِنَّا إِذَا نَزَلْنَا بِسَاحَةِ قَوْمٍ فَسَاءَ صَبَاحُ الْمُنْذَرِينَ>> (Indeed, when We descend upon the territory of a people, then wretched is the morning of those who were warned).

### [There is no Exoteric Ruling in the Sacred Law (الشريعة) without an Esoteric Counterpart]

There is no ruling among the obligatory acts (فرائض), recommended practices (سنن), or desirable acts (استحبابات) of the Sacred Law (الشريعة) that does not have an inner (الباطن) ruling, or more, corresponding to what is unveiled (يفتح) to the servant (العبد) concerning it, whether it is obligatory, recommended, or desirable. This is necessary. This principle applies to all legislated acts of worship (العبادات المشروعة). By this, the ruling of the outer (الظاهر) is distinguished from the inner (الباطن). For the outer flows into the inner, but there is no legislated inner matter that flows into the outer; rather, it is restricted to the inner. This is because the inner (الباطن) consists entirely of meanings (معان), while the outer (الظاهر) consists of perceptible actions (أفعال محسوسة). Thus, one moves from the perceptible to the meaning, but one does not move from the meaning to the perceptible.

(Chapter on Defining the Limits of Washing the Face)

There is no disagreement that washing the face is obligatory (فرض). Its ruling in the esoteric realm (الباطن) is absolute mindfulness (المراقبة) and shame (الحياء) before Allah. This means that you do not transgress the limits of Allah the Exalted. The scholars of external rulings (علماء الرسوم) differed regarding the definition of the limits of washing the face in ablution (الوضوء) in three areas: first, the white space between the sideburn (العذار) and the ear; second, the part of the beard that hangs down; and third, washing the beard. Regarding the aforementioned white space, some say it is part of the face, and others say it is not. Regarding the part of the beard that hangs down, some say it is obligatory to pass water over it, and others say it is not obligatory. Regarding running water through the beard (تخليل اللحية), some say it is obligatory, and others say it is not.

(Continuation on the Esoteric Ruling of What We Have Mentioned)

### [Washing the Face from the Esoteric Perspective]

As for washing the face absolutely, without regard to defining its limits, part of it is obligatory (فرض) and part of it is not obligatory. The obligatory part is the shame (الحياء) before Allah that He should see you where He forbade you, or miss you where He commanded you. The recommended part (السنة) is the shame before Allah that you should uncover your nakedness (عورتك) in your solitude. Allah is more deserving that you should feel shame before Him, even though you know that there is no part of you that He does not see. However, the ruling concerning your actions, insofar as you are held responsible (مكلف), is what we have mentioned, and the tradition (الخبر) has confirmed it. Likewise, looking at the nakedness of your wife, even though it is permissible for you, applying shame in this regard is better and more appropriate. Thus, the obligation falls away in this context—I mean, in the context of shame—as in His saying: <<لَا يَسْتَحْيِي مِنَ الْحَقِّ>> (Allah is not ashamed of the truth). So, whatever is specifically determined (يتعين) is obligatory upon you, and whatever is not specifically determined is a recommended practice (سنة) or desirable act (استحباب). If you wish, you perform it, and that is better; and if you wish, you do not perform it. Therefore, a person should be mindful (يراقب) of his actions and omissions, both outwardly (ظاهرا) and inwardly (باطنا), and be mindful of the traces of his Lord in his heart, for the face (وجه) of his heart is what is considered. The face of a human and of everything is its reality (حقيقته), its Essence (ذاته), and its immutable entity (عينه). One says "the face of the thing," "the face of the issue," or "the face of the ruling," meaning by this face the reality of the named thing, its entity, and its Essence. Allah the Exalted said: <<وُجُوهٌ يَوْمَئِذٍ نَاضِرَةٌ إِلَى رَبِّهَا نَاظِرَةٌ>> (Faces, that Day, will be radiant, looking at their Lord), and <<وَوُجُوهٌ يَوْمَئِذٍ بَاسِرَةٌ تَظُنُّ أَنْ يُفْعَلَ بِهَا فَاقِرَةٌ>> (And faces, that Day, will be frowning, expecting that a back-breaking calamity will be inflicted upon them). The faces that are on the front of the human are not described by expectations (الظنون); rather, the expectation belongs to the reality (حقيقة) of the human.

Thus, shame (الحياء) is entirely good, and shame is part of faith, and shame brings nothing but good.

### [The Dividing Line Between the Function of the Face and the Function of Hearing]

As for the white space between the sideburn (العذار) and the ear, which is the dividing line between the face and the ear, it is the boundary between the action a person is responsible for concerning his face and the action concerning his hearing. The action here is the inclusion of the boundary within the bounded area. It is more appropriate for a person to apply his shame (حياءه) to his hearing, just as he applies it to his sight. Just as lowering the gaze from what Allah has forbidden is part of shame, Allah the Exalted said to His Messenger (صلى الله عليه وسلم): <<قُلْ لِلْمُؤْمِنِينَ يَغُضُّوا مِنْ أَبْصَارِهِمْ>> (Tell the believing men to reduce [some] of their vision) and <<وَقُلْ لِلْمُؤْمِنَاتِ يَغْضُضْنَ مِنْ أَبْصَارِهِنَّ>> (And tell the believing women to reduce [some] of their vision). The inner meaning (باطن) of these two verses addresses the soul (النفس) and the intellect (العقل). Likewise, shame before Allah obligates him not to listen to what is unlawful for him to hear, such as backbiting (غيبة) or evil speech from someone uttering what is inappropriate or unlawful for him to pronounce. That white space between the sideburn and the ear is the locus of ambiguity (الشبهة). The form of ambiguity here is that he might say: "I only listened to him so that I could refute him and defend the person who was backbitten." This is from the jurisprudence of the soul (فقه النفس). His saying this is related to the sideburn (العذار), for it comes from the word for excuse (*al-udhr*). That is, when a person is blamed for this, he offers an excuse (يعتذر) like the one mentioned, saying: "I only listened to confirm what he said so that I could forbid him from it with certainty." Thus, it is symbolized by the sideburn. And for one who has no sideburns, it is the place where the sideburn would be. Whoever deems this obligatory upon himself washes it, based on what Allah the Exalted said: <<الَّذِينَ يَسْتَمِعُونَ الْقَوْلَ فَيَتَّبِعُونَ أَحْسَنَهُ أُولَئِكَ الَّذِينَ هَدَاهُمُ اللَّهُ>> (Those who listen to the word and follow the best of it—those are the ones whom Allah has guided), meaning He made clear to them the good from the ugly in that matter, <<وَأُولَئِكَ هُمْ أُولُو الْأَلْبَابِ>> (and those are the people of understanding [أُولُو الْأَلْبَاب]), meaning they understood what We intended, and *al-lubb* is the core of a thing protected by the husk. And whoever does not deem this obligatory upon himself may wash it if he wishes, or omit it if he wishes. This is like someone who listens to a person of authority whom he fears might transgress against him, and he is unable to refute the speech to his face. If he is able to leave the gathering, he departs—that is his washing, if he wishes. But if remaining seated is preferable to him for a matter he deems probable, he sits and does not leave. This applies according to those who do not deem it obligatory upon him.

### [Washing the Part of the Beard That Hangs Down and Running Water Through It]

As for washing the part of the beard that hangs down and running water through it, these correspond to accidental matters (الأمور العوارض). The beard is something that appears on the face; it is not intrinsically part of the face, nor is it included in its definition. This is analogous to issues external to your Essence (ذاتك) that arise concerning you. In these matters, you are subject to the ruling of that accidental factor. If the purification of your soul (طهارة نفسك) from that accidental factor is specifically determined (تعين) upon you, this validates the opinion of those who say washing it is obligatory. If its purification is not specifically determined upon you, and you purify it as a desirable act (استحبابا) or omit it because it was not determined upon you—though its omission is a deficiency in general—this validates the opinion of those who say it is not obligatory, which is the doctrine of the others. We have already explained to you in previous sections of this chapter that the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) in these matters differs from the exoteric ruling (حكم الظاهر) in that it has an aspect of obligation (الفرضية) and an aspect of recommended practice (السنة) and desirability (الاستحباب). The obligatory must be acted upon, whether by commission or omission. As for the non-obligatory, it is better to treat it in compliance as if it were obligatory, both in commission and omission. This applies to all other acts of worship (العبادات).

(Chapter on Washing the Hands and Forearms in Ablution up to the Elbows)

The scholars of the Sacred Law (الشريعة) unanimously agreed on washing the hands and forearms (الذراعين) with water during ablution. They differed regarding the inclusion of the elbows (المرافق) in the washing. Our doctrine is to adhere to the point of consensus in the action, for consensus in the ruling is inconceivable. Some say it is obligatory to include them in the washing, and others say it is not obligatory. There is no disagreement among those who deny the obligation that it is desirable (استحباب) to include them in the washing.

(Continuation on the Esoteric Ruling in That Regard)

### [Washing the Hands with Generosity and the Forearms with Reliance (التوكل)]

I say, after establishing the exoteric ruling (حكم الظاهر) by which Allah has commanded us to worship: The washing of the hands and forearms (الذراعين)—which are the wrists (المعصمان)—is the washing of the hands with generosity (الكرم), munificence (الجود), liberality (السخاء), altruism (الإيثار), gifts (الهبات), and the fulfillment of trusts (الأمانات)—which is where altruism is not valid. Likewise, one washes them, along with the forearms, by holding fast (الاعتصام) up to the elbows (المرافق) through reliance upon God (التوكل) and mutual support (الاعتضاد), for the believer is strengthened by his brother. Indeed, the Messenger of Allah (صلى الله عليه وسلم), when washing his forearms in ablution, would pass beyond the elbows until he began washing the upper arm (العضد). This and similar actions are descriptions of the hands. The disagreement regarding the limit of the hands mostly extends up to the armpits (الآباط), and minimally to the joint from which the forearm is named. Thus, the inclusion of the elbows remains.

### [The Elbows (المرافق) or Seeing the Means (الأسباب) for Comfort and Familiarity]

The elbows (المرافق) in the esoteric realm (الباطن) represent the perception of the means (الأسباب) by which the servant (العبد) finds comfort (يرتفق) and his soul finds familiarity (تأنس). For man, in his original creation, <<خُلِقَ هَلُوعًا>> (was created anxious), fearing the poverty that his reality (حقيقته) grants him by virtue of his contingency (إمكانه). Thus, he inclines toward and leans upon what gives him comfort. Whoever deems the inclusion of the elbows in his washing obligatory sees that Allah established the means (الأسباب) as an act of wisdom (حكمة) in His creation, knowing the weakness of their certainty (يقينهم). He thus desires not to nullify Allah's wisdom, but not by way of reliance upon them, for that would impair his reliance upon Allah (اعتماده على الله). And whoever deems their inclusion in the washing non-obligatory sees that the soul's tranquility toward the means prevents him from achieving the station of reliance upon Allah (الاعتماد على الله) immediately, even while perceiving the means. Everyone who says they are not obligatory still recommends their inclusion in the washing. Likewise, the perception of the means is recommended by all, even if their rulings concerning them differ, for Allah has linked wisdom (الحكمة) to their existence.

(Chapter on Wiping the Head)

### [The Difference Among Scholars Regarding the Obligatory Amount of Wiping the Head]

The scholars of the Sacred Law (الشريعة) agreed that wiping the head is one of the obligatory acts (فرائض) of ablution. They differed regarding the obligatory amount. Some say it is obligatory to wipe the entire head, and others say it is obligatory to wipe only a part of it. They differed on the limit of this part: some say one-third is obligatory, some say two-thirds, some say one-fourth, and some say there is no limit to the part. Some of these scholars discussed the limit of the amount of the hand used for wiping. Some say that wiping with less than three fingers is insufficient, and others say there is no limit to the part, neither in what is wiped nor in what is used to wipe. The root of this disagreement is the presence of the particle *bā’* (ب) in His saying, the Exalted: <<بِرُؤُوسِكُمْ>> (with your heads).

(Continuation on the Esoteric Ruling of Wiping)

### [The Head is the Closest Organ to The Real (الحق) Due to the Correspondence of Above]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم المسح في الباطن) of wiping the head, by way of consideration, the head derives from *al-ri’āsa* (superiority), which means loftiness and elevation. From this comes *ra’īs al-qawm* (chief of the people), meaning their master who holds authority over them. Since it is the highest part of the body outwardly, and the entire body is beneath it, it is called *ra’s* (head), because the chief is above the subordinate in rank and has the direction of above. Allah described Himself with the attribute of aboveness (الفوقية) due to its nobility. Allah the Exalted said: <<يَخَافُونَ رَبَّهُمْ مِنْ فَوْقِهِمْ>> (They fear their Lord from above them), and He said: <<وَهُوَ الْقَاهِرُ فَوْقَ عِبَادِهِ>> (And He is the Subduer, above His servants). Thus, the head is the closest organ in the body to The Real (الحق) due to the correspondence of above.

### [The Intellect (العقل): Its Locus is the Fontanelle (اليافوخ), the Highest Part of the Head]

Furthermore, the head has another nobility due to the meaning by which it presides over all parts of the body: namely, that it is a comprehensive locus carrying all powers (القوي), both perceptible and intelligible/spiritual (المعقولة المعنوية). Since it also possesses this superiority (الرياسة) from this perspective, it is called *ra’s*. Moreover, the intellect (العقل), which Allah made the noblest thing in man, has its locus placed in the highest part of the head, which is the fontanelle (اليافوخ), thus placing it adjacent to the direction of aboveness (الفوقية).

### [The Head: The Confluence of the Outer and the Inner]

Since the head is the locus for all outer (الظاهرة) and inner (الباطنة) powers, and each power has a ruling, authority, and pride that grants it honor (عزة) over others—like the palace of the king compared to the houses of commoners—and since Allah made the loci of these powers within the head distinct, encompassing the entire head—its top, middle, front, and back—and since every power, as we mentioned, possesses honor, authority, and inherent arrogance (كبرياء) and superiority (رياسة), it is obligatory to wipe the entire head. This is the consideration of those who say wiping the entire head is obligatory, due to this superiority that permeates the whole head, stemming from its bearing these powers of different locations, through humility (التواضع) and submission (الإقناع) to Allah. Thus, when the wiping is comprehensive, each power receives a specific wiping corresponding to its claim, thereby restraining it with the wiping specific to it, so the entire head is covered by the wiping. And whoever sees that the head has a head over it—just as governors appointed by the Sultan refer their affairs back to him, for he is the one who appointed them—sees that every governor has a superior governor above him who has authority over his authority. This is like the formative power (القوة المصورة) having authority over the imaginative power (القوة الخيالية), being superior to it, even though the imaginative power itself possesses superiority. Whoever among the scholars holds this view says that wiping only a part of the head is sufficient, which signifies focusing on the highest (الأعلى).

### [The Servant Standing in the Locus of Abasement (الإذلال), Not with the Attribute of Presumption (الإدلال) with the Hard *Dāl*]

Then our companions differed regarding this part. Every Gnostic (عارف) spoke according to the realization (الإدراك) Allah granted him concerning the levels (مراتب) of these powers, based on what he perceives and considers. He proceeds to wipe in this act of worship, which is abasement (التذلل) and the removal of arrogance (الكبرياء) and loftiness (الشموخ) through humility (التواضع) and servitude (العبودية), because in the purification of worship, he seeks connection (الوصلة) with his Lord. For the one praying is in the station of intimate conversation (مناجاة) with his Lord, which is the connection sought through purification. The honored chief (العزيز الرئيس), when entering upon the one who granted him that honor and authority, descends from his authority and abases himself from his honor before the honor of the one he enters upon, who is his Master (سيده) who brought him into existence. He stands before Him like other servants (العبيد) who have lowered themselves to a station of no standing by seeking recompense. This servant stands in the locus of abasement (الإذلال), not with the attribute of presumption (*al-idlal*). Whoever is dominated by the thought of the superiority of some powers over others must wipe that specific part for the sake of the connection he seeks through this worship. For this reason, wiping the head was not legislated in dry ablution (التيمم), because placing dust (التراب) on the head is a sign of separation (الفراق) and a great calamity, as one who loses his beloved through death places dust on his head. Since the goal of this worship is connection (الوصلة), not separation (الفرقة), wiping the head was not legislated in dry ablution. So, wipe according to the limit we have mentioned and alerted you to. The detailed explanation of the superiorities of the powers is known among the Sufi community (الطائفة); I do not need to mention it. As for the partiality (التبعيض) in the hand used for wiping and the disagreement concerning it, treat it exactly as you treat the wiped area. The removal of this superiority (الرياسة) involves various means (أسباب) related to the capacity (القدرة) for that, and the locus of this is the hand. Some remove it by way of subjugation (القهر), and some by policy and encouragement, just as a person wipes the head of an orphan with his hand to mend his brokenness with kindness and tenderness. For this reason, the hand's partiality and totality in wiping are considered. Know this.

### [Does Contingent Power (القدرة الحادثة) Have an Effect on the Predetermined (المقدور)?]

Since the cause of this disagreement among the scholars is the presence of the particle *bā’* (ب) in His saying <<بِرُؤُوسِكُمْ>> (with your heads), whoever takes it to mean partiality (التبعيض) wipes only a part, and whoever takes it as an augmentative particle for emphasis (التوكيد) in the wiping wipes the entire head. The *bā’* in this context represents the existence of contingent power (القدرة الحادثة). This power either has an effect on the predetermined act (المقدور), in which case partiality is valid—which is the view of the Mu'tazilite and others—or it has no effect on the predetermined act whatsoever, in which case it is augmentative, as the Ash'ari says. Its ruling thus falls away, and the Eternal Power (القدرة القديمة) encompasses the wiping of the entire head; the contingent power does not make the wiping partial. The limit of observing the emphasis, by virtue of the particle being augmentative for emphasis, is the acquisition (*al-iktisāb*) asserted by the Ash'aris. This is supported by Allah the Exalted's statement in various places in His Book, attributing acquisition and action to the created being. For this reason, they considered its augmentation to signify a meaning called emphasis (التوكيد).

### [The Arabs Counter the Augmentative with the Augmentative in Their Speech]

Do you not see that the Arabs counter the augmentative with the augmentative in their speech, intending emphasis (التوكيد) by it, and respond with it when the speaker emphasizes his statement? The speaker might say, "Indeed, Zayd is standing," or "Zayd is not standing." The listener, in response to "Indeed, Zayd is standing," says, "Zayd is not standing," and in response to "Zayd is not standing," he affirms what the speaker negated or negates what the speaker affirmed. If the speaker emphasizes his affirmation by saying, "Indeed, Zayd is certainly standing (إن زيدا لقائم)," introducing the *lām* (ل) to emphasize the affirmation of standing, the respondent introduces the *bā’* (ب) in opposition to the *lām* to emphasize the negation of what the speaker affirmed, saying, "Zayd is not standing (ما زيد بقائم)." Such a particle is called augmentative (زائدا) because the sentence is complete without it. However, if the speaker intends something other than partiality and uses that particle for emphasis, it is augmentative. But if he intends partiality, that particle is not augmentative at all. The external form is the same, but the meaning differs, and the consideration is solely for the intention of the speaker who established that form.

### [The Origin of the Disagreement Among Speculative Theologians (النظار) Regarding the Creation of Actions]

When we are ignorant of the meaning for which the Exalted created the ability to perform certain actions—which we find within ourselves and do not deny, namely voluntary movement (الحركة الاختيارية)—just as He placed within us the impediment to certain actions apparent in us, which we also find within ourselves, such as the movement of a tremor, in which the trembling person has no choice—we do not know to what that ability (التمكن) we find in ourselves is attributed: Is it attributed to the contingent power (القدرة الحادثة) within us having an effect on that existing entity (العين الموجودة) resulting from our ability, or is it attributed to the will (الإرادة) created within us, such that the ability is the effect of the will, not the effect of the contingent power? From here arises the disagreement among the speculative theologians (أصحاب النظر) on this issue. Based on this, man ought to be held responsible (مكلفا) due to the very ability he finds within himself, without needing to ascertain with his intellect (عقله) to what that ability is attributed—whether to his being capable or to his being choosing, even if he is compelled in his choice. But by that measure of ability he finds in himself, it is valid for him to be held responsible. For this reason, Allah the Exalted said: <<لَا يُكَلِّفُ اللَّهُ نَفْسًا إِلَّا مَا آتَاهَا>> (Allah does not charge a soul except [with that which] He has given it). He has given it an existent matter; it cannot be said that He gave it nothing. And we have not seen anything He gave it without dispute except the ability (التمكن), which is its capacity (وسعها): <<لَا يُكَلِّفُ اللَّهُ نَفْسًا إِلَّا وُسْعَهَا>> (Allah does not charge a soul except [with] its capacity).

### [Every Theoretical Issue Must Involve Disagreement Due to the Difference in Innate Dispositions (الفطر) Regarding Speculation]

And one does not know to what this ability (التمكن) and this capacity (الوسع) are attributed: Is it to one of them—meaning the will (الإرادة) or the power (القدرة)—or to something additional to both, or to both? This is known only through Unveiling (الكشف). It is not possible for us to reveal the truth in this matter, because doing so would not remove the disagreement from the world concerning it, as the disagreement was removed for us through Unveiling. And how can disagreement be removed from the world when the issue is intelligible? Every intelligible issue must involve disagreement due to the difference in innate dispositions (الفطر) regarding speculation. You have now understood what wiping the head means in this spiritual path (الطريقة). What remains of its ruling is wiping over the turban (العمامة) and the ruling contained therein.

(Continuation on Wiping Over the Turban)

Some scholars of the Sacred Law (الشريعة) permitted wiping over the turban (العمامة), while a group prohibited it. Those who prohibited it did so because it contradicts the implication of the verse, for the turban is not understood to be the head, and covering the head is an accidental matter (أمر عارض). Those who permitted it did so because of the tradition (الخبر) mentioned in *Sahih Muslim*, although Abu Umar ibn Abd al-Barr said that this hadith is defective (معلول).

(Continuation on the Esoteric Ruling of Wiping the Turban)

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم المسح على العمامة في الباطن) of wiping over the turban, know that accidental matters (الأمور العوارض) do not contradict the fundamental principles (الأصول) nor impair them. What you should consider is the reason necessitating the occurrence of that accidental factor. It must either be something dispensable, or something whose loss causes harm, making it indispensable. If it is dispensable, it has no ruling regarding the removal of the fundamental ruling. If it is indispensable and its loss causes harm, its ruling is the same as the fundamental principle, and it acts as its substitute. If a part of the fundamental principle remains, that remaining part must necessarily be observed. And the remaining part of the fundamental principle is substituted by this accidental matter whose loss causes harm. This is our doctrine concerning it. For this reason, it is mentioned in the hadith—which we noted is considered defective by some scholars of this discipline—that the wiping occurred over the forelock (الناصية) and the turban (العمامة) together. Thus, the water touched the hair, and the ruling of the fundamental principle was achieved according to the doctrine of those who say wiping part of the head is sufficient. If one wore the turban merely for adornment (الزينة), it would not be permissible for him to wipe over it, unlike the sick person who ties the turban on his head due to illness. Nothing has been transmitted that can withstand the explicit text of the Quran on this issue.

### [Undertaking the Means (الأسباب) for One Who is Stripped of Means]

If an accidental factor arises for the people of this spiritual path (الطريقة) that impairs the fundamental principle—such as undertaking a means (فعل السبب) for one who is stripped of means, or strutting and displaying authority (الرئاسة) in war (since our discussion is about wiping the head, which relates to humility, using arrogance as an example is more appropriate so that the listener's understanding reaches the intended meaning of this worship)—the effect of that vanity is the manifestation of pride (الكبر) in the human's servitude (عبودية), leading to the forgetting of the Majesty (كبرياء) and Honor (عزته) of his Lord, the Exalted, and veiling him from it. Therefore, he must not do it and must cast off pride from himself. It is not permissible for him to be arrogant in that situation because it impairs the fundamental principle. But if it does not affect his soul—rather, it is an outward matter visible to the enemy, while he himself remains in his abasement (ذلته) and neediness (افتقاره)—then the outward form of arrogance is permissible for him due to the contextual indication (قرينة الحال) based on the situation, because it did not impair the fundamental principle. This is the ruling concerning wiping over the turban according to us. Know this.

### [Casting Off the Means (السبب) from the Hand is a Part of the Hand's Actions]

You have learned the esoteric ruling of wiping over the turban. Likewise, wiping over the turban with part of the hand means that if your taking of the means (السبب) impairs your reliance upon Allah (اعتمادك على الله) in your heart, then do not take it or use it, unless omitting it leads to something greater in distance from Allah. If it does not affect your reliance upon Him, then wipe with part of your hand, and there is no blame upon you. For casting off the means from the hand is a part of the hand's actions, because the totality of the hand, in meaning, involves many matters. It performs many actions with varying meanings in legislated matters and rulings, for it involves grasping (القبض), extending (البسط), and moderation (الاعتدال). Allah the Exalted said: <<وَلَا تَجْعَلْ يَدَكَ مَغْلُولَةً إِلَى عُنُقِكَ>> (And do not make your hand chained to your neck), which is a metaphor for stinginess (البخل), <<وَلَا تَبْسُطْهَا كُلَّ الْبَسْطِ>> (nor extend it completely), which is a metaphor for extravagance (السرف). Likewise, He praised a people with a similar description, saying: <<وَالَّذِينَ إِذَا أَنْفَقُوا لَمْ يُسْرِفُوا وَلَمْ يَقْتُرُوا وَكَانَ بَيْنَ ذَلِكَ قَوَامًا>> (And those who, when they spend, are neither extravagant nor stingy, but maintain a just balance between the two), which is justice in spending. Likewise, He said: <<وَلَا تُلْقُوا بِأَيْدِيكُمْ إِلَى التَّهْلُكَةِ>> (And do not throw [yourselves] with your own hands into destruction), which here means stinginess. He attributed all of this to the hands. For this reason, we said the hand has many actions. Were it not for the existence of multiplicity (الكثرة), partiality (البعضية) would not be valid, because the One does not admit of parts.

(Continuation on the Timing of Wiping the Head)

### [Is Repeating the Wiping of the Head a Virtue (فضيلة)?]

What remains to be verified concerning this issue is the timing of wiping the head: Is there a virtue (فضيلة) in repeating it or not? Some people said there is no virtue in it, and others said there is. This repetition is recommended in all actions of ablution across all its organs equally, except that the repetition is stronger in some organs and weaker in others. There is no disagreement on the obligation of a single wiping/washing if it covers the organ entirely.

### [There is No Repetition in the World Due to Divine Expansion (الاتساع الإلهي)]

As for our doctrine concerning the fundamental principle, there is no repetition (تكرار) in the world (العالم) due to Divine Expansion (الاتساع الإلهي). Thus, we prohibit this term [repetition], but we do not prohibit the existence of similar instances (الأمثال) through formal resemblance (التشابه الصوري). We know with certainty that movements resemble one another in form, even though each one is not the exact same entity as the other. Our doctrine is to look at the ruling of the Lawgiver (الشارع) concerning this. If He counted by similar instances, we count by similar instances, just as we say *Subhān Allāh* thirty-three times after the prayer. We do not prohibit such a thing. Multiplicity may occur in the act of ablution to emphasize the removal of the effect of the rapid heedlessness (الغفلات) in man. In this case, there is virtue (فضيلة) in repetition. But if one is certain of presence (الحضور), there is no virtue. For virtue (الفضل) is the surplus. If this person performing ablution did not increase the ruling due to heedlessness or forgetfulness, and yet repeats, the surplus is not valid. However, the correct view according to us is that repetition contains virtue because it is a light (نور) corresponding to the limit set by the Lawgiver who clarifies the rulings. It has been mentioned in the Book and the Sunnah regarding the likeness of Allah's Light to a lamp in a glass within a niche—the verse in its entirety—and He said at the end of it: <<نُورٌ عَلَى نُورٍ>> (Light upon Light), meaning that light upon light is mentioned, like two or three proofs for a single signified meaning. And the Messenger of Allah (صلى الله عليه وسلم) said concerning ablution upon ablution: "Light upon Light (نُورٌ عَلَى نُورٍ)."

There is no difference between performing ablution upon ablution and the second scoop of water following the first in ablution. The repetition of the action by the agent necessitates the repetition of the reward and the Theophany (التجلي). As for all the organs, repetition is established. The disagreement was only concerning the head, the ears, and the feet, and we have alluded to what is appropriate in that regard.

(Chapter on Wiping the Ears and Renewing Water for Them)

### [The Difference Among Jurists Regarding the Ruling on Wiping the Ears]

People differed regarding wiping the ears and renewing the water for them. Some say it is a recommended practice (سنة), and some say it is obligatory (فرض). Some say water must be renewed for them, and some say water should not be renewed for them. Should they be wiped alone, or wiped specifically with the head, or wiped specifically with the face, or should the part facing forward be wiped with the face and the part facing backward be wiped with the head? There is a proponent for each of these situations.

(Continuation on Their Esoteric Ruling)

### [Listening to the Best Word: The Remembrance of Allah in the Quran]

As for their esoteric ruling (حكمهما في الباطن), the ear is an independent organ for which water must be renewed. It is wiped by listening to the best word (القول الأحسن), which is necessary. There is a gradation in "the best": there is good (*hasan*) and better (*ahsan*). The highest in goodness is the remembrance of Allah (ذكر الله) through the Quran, thus combining the two good things. There is nothing higher than hearing the remembrance of Allah. This means every verse in the Quran whose signified meaning is none other than Allah. Not all verses of the Quran contain the remembrance of Allah, for it contains legislated rulings, the stories of the Pharaohs, and accounts of their sayings and disbelief. Although listening to the reciter when he reads it, or listening to oneself when reciting it, brings great reward insofar as it is the Quran, the remembrance of Allah in the Quran is better and more complete than the recounting of the disbeliever's inappropriate speech about Allah, even when it is found in the Quran.

### [The Outer and Inner of the Ear, and the Clear (محكم) and Ambiguous (متشابه) Parts of the Quran]

As for the part of the outer ear that faces forward and the part that faces backward, they correspond to what is manifest of the ruling of that remembrance from the Quran and what is hidden, what is secret and what is declared, what is understood and what is unknown. Thus, you submit the ambiguous words (كلمات المتشابه) concerning Allah to Allah. This corresponds to the part facing backward from the inner ear (باطن الأذن), which is submitted to the intention of Allah the Exalted concerning them when the ear hears them recited. And what is known, such as the clear verses (الآيات المحكمات) concerning Allah and what they indicate regarding the created realms (الأكوان), corresponds to the part facing forward from the outer ear (ظاهر الأذن). The intention of Allah concerning them is known, and the ruling is according to what the knowledge relates to. So, act according to what we have indicated to you in this detail. It is preferable that the ruling of the ears be the same as the ruling for rinsing the mouth (المضمضة), sniffing water (الاستنشاق), and cleansing the nasal passage (الاستنثار).

(Chapter on Washing the Feet)

### [The Purification of the Feet: By Washing, Wiping, or Choice]

Know that the form of its timing in washing by number is the same as the form of the head, and we have mentioned that. Scholars agreed that the feet are among the organs of ablution. They differed regarding the form of their purification: Is it by washing (الغسل), wiping (المسح), or by choice (التخيير) between the two, such that whichever one is performed, the other is dropped, and the obligation is fulfilled? This is when no leather socks (خف) are worn. Our doctrine is choice, though combining them is better. There is no opinion without a proponent. Wiping is supported by the apparent meaning of the Book [Quran], and washing by the Sunnah, and the verse is susceptible to interpretation by deviating from its apparent meaning.

(Continuation on the Esoteric Ruling of the Feet)

### [What Purifies the Feet]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم ذلك في الباطن), know that striving toward congregational prayers (الجماعات), increasing steps toward the mosques (المساجد), and standing firm on the day of battle (يوم الزحف) are among the things that purify the feet (الأقدام). Let the purification of your feet be by what we have mentioned and its like. Do not walk with slander (النميمة) among people, and <<وَلَا تَمْشِ فِي الْأَرْضِ مَرَحًا>> (and do not walk upon the earth exultantly), and <<وَاقْصِدْ فِي مَشْيِكَ>> (and be moderate in your pace). Part of this—I mean, of these actions—is obligatory (فرض), equivalent to the single washing of an ablution organ, whether the foot or otherwise. And part of it is recommended (سنة), which is what exceeds the obligatory, namely your walking toward what the Law has encouraged you to strive for, and what it has obligated upon you. What is obligatory upon you is moving your feet to your place of prayer. The recommended (المندوب), the desirable (المستحب), and the Sunnah—call it what you will—is moving the feet to the mosques, whether near or far, for that is not obligatory, even though some people consider the movement to a specific mosque or a specific congregation obligatory. Based on this, the washing of your feet in the esoteric realm is by way of meaning.

### [What Actions Necessitate Specificity and Generality]

Know that washing (الغسل) inherently includes wiping (المسح) in one aspect. Whoever washes has included wiping within it, just as the light of the stars is included in the light of the sun. And whoever wipes has not washed, except according to the doctrine of those who hold and transmit from the Arabs that *al-mash* (wiping) is linguistically equivalent to *al-ghusl* (washing), making them synonymous terms. The correct meaning in the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) is that wiping (المسح) should be used for actions that necessitate specificity (الخصوص), and washing (الغسل) for actions that necessitate generality (العموم). This is the ideal path (الطريقة المثلى). For this reason, we adopted the choice (التخيير) based on the time (الوقت). One might strive for a specific virtue concerning a particular need for a specific person—that is equivalent to wiping. Or one might strive toward the King for a need that encompasses all subjects and their needs, and that specific person is included in this generality—this is equivalent to washing, in which wiping is included.

(Clarification and Completion)

### [Our Doctrine is that the *Fatha* on the *Lām* Does Not Exclude it from Being Wiped]

As for the recitation of His saying <<وَأَرْجُلَكُمْ>> (and your feet) with the *fatha* (accusative) on the *lām* or the *kasra* (genitive) due to the letter *wāw* (and), where it is an attribution to the wiped part (المنسوح) by the genitive, and to the washed part (المغسول) by the accusative—our doctrine is that the *fatha* on the *lām* does not exclude it from being wiped. This *wāw* may be the *wāw* of accompaniment (*wāw ma‘iyya*), which governs the accusative. You say: "Zayd stood, and ‘Amrān," and "The water and the wood were level," and "What are you and a bowl of *tharīd*," and "I passed by Zayd and ‘Amrān," meaning "with ‘Amr." Likewise, for those who recite <<وَامْسَحُوا بِرُؤُوسِكُمْ وَأَرْجُلَكُمْ>> with the *fatha* on the *lām*, the argument of those who advocate wiping (المسح) in this verse is stronger, because they share with those who advocate washing (الغسل) the indication they considered, which is the *fatha* on the *lām*, whereas those who advocate washing do not share the indication of the *kasra* on the *lām*. Some of our companions prefer the specific (الخاص) over the general (العام), and some prefer the general over the specific, all absolutely.

### [Walking with The Real (الحق) According to the State (الحال)]

Our doctrine is different from that. We only walk with The Real (الحق) according to the state (الحال). We generalize where He generalized and specify where He specified. We do not innovate a ruling (حكما), for whoever innovates a ruling has innovated Lordship (ربوبية) within himself. Whoever innovates Lordship within himself has diminished his servitude (عبوديته) by the measure of that issue. When his servitude is diminished by that measure, the Theophany (تجلى) of The Real to him is diminished. When the Theophany of The Real to him is diminished, his knowledge (علمه) of his Lord is diminished. And when his knowledge of his Lord is diminished, he is ignorant of Him, the Exalted, by the measure of that diminution. If a ruling appears in the world (العالم) or in his own world that was diminished, he will not recognize it. For this reason, our doctrine is not to innovate any ruling whatsoever.

(Chapter on the Sequence of Ablution Actions)

### [The Difference Among Scholars Regarding the Sequence of Ablution Actions]

Scholars differed regarding the sequence (ترتيب) of ablution actions as they appeared in the order of the verse. Some say the sequence is obligatory (وجوب الترتيب), and some say it is not obligatory. This applies to the obligatory actions. As for the sequence of obligatory actions with recommended actions, their disagreement concerns whether it is a recommended practice (سنة) or a desirable act (استحباب).

(Continuation on the Esoteric Ruling in That Regard)

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم ذلك في الباطن), there is no sequence (ترتيب). Rather, you perform the action according to what is specifically determined (تعين) upon you at that time (الوقت). If what is appropriate for your head is determined upon you, you perform it and begin with it. The same applies to the rest. Whether this concerns recommended actions (السنن) or obligatory actions (الفرائض), the ruling belongs to the time.

(Chapter on Continuity (Al-Muwālāt) in Ablution)

### [The Difference Among Jurists Regarding Continuity in Ablution]

Some say that continuity (الموالاة) is obligatory (فرض) when one remembers and has no excuse, but it is dropped with forgetfulness, and also when one remembers but has an excuse, provided the gap is not excessive. Others say that continuity is not obligatory. All of this stems from the reality of the order of the verse. The *wāw* (and) may conjoin things that follow immediately, or things that are separated by a delay, or it may conjoin two actions occurring simultaneously. This simultaneous action is not possible in ablution unless one immerses oneself in a river or people pour water over each organ at the same time.

(Continuation on Continuity in the Esoteric Realm)

### [Our Doctrine Regarding Continuity (الموالاة) is That It Is Not Obligatory]

Our doctrine regarding the esoteric ruling (حكم الموالاة في الباطن) of continuity is that it is not obligatory, just like the sequence (الترتيب). We perform the action according to what the time (الوقت) necessitates. We have mentioned the parallel of this issue in the *Risālat al-Anwār* (Treatise of Lights) concerning the secrets granted to the one in spiritual retreat (الخلوة).

### [The Actions of the Path (الطريق) According to the Time and What It Grants]

Our actions in this spiritual path (الطريق) are according to the ruling of the time and what it grants. Man has been decreed to experience heedlessness (الغفلات), so continuity (الموالاة) is not possible for him alongside that, but rather moment by moment. It is not within human capacity to maintain mindfulness (مراقبة الله) of Allah in secret and in public with every breath. General continuity is not achieved unless one exerts effort in self-presence (الاستحضار) and mindfulness in all his actions. Allah the Exalted said: <<الَّذِينَ هُمْ عَلَى صَلَاتِهِمْ دَائِمُونَ>> (Those who are constant in their prayers). What is meant by this is that whenever the time for prayer comes, they perform it, even if there are other matters between the prayers. Thus, constancy is achieved in a specific action tied to distinct times. As for maintaining it with every breath, that is among the characteristics of the Highest Assembly (الملإ الأعلى) who <<يُسَبِّحُونَ اللَّيْلَ وَالنَّهَارَ لَا يَفْتُرُونَ>> (glorify [Him] night and day, and do not slacken). This is true continuity (الموالاة), and if it occurs for some men of Allah (رجال الله), it is rare.

### [The Messenger of Allah (صلى الله عليه وسلم) Used to Remember Allah at All Times]

The saying of Aisha: "The Messenger of Allah (صلى الله عليه وسلم) used to remember Allah at all times." If she transmitted this from the Messenger of Allah (صلى الله عليه وسلم), we do not doubt it. If she meant by it that none of his outward actions were merely permissible (مباح) at all, and that he was always engaged in an obligatory or recommended act, that is possible and apparent from his rank, for he taught his community through his movements and stillness for them to emulate. Thus, he is constantly remembering. As for his inner reality (باطنه), peace be upon him, she had no knowledge of it except through his own informing (صلى الله عليه وسلم). Nevertheless, according to us, achieving this is conceivable even while engaging in the permissible (المباح), provided he maintains presence (حضوره) that it is permissible. Likewise, if he maintains the presence of the ruling of the Sacred Law in all his movements and stillness to this degree, he is among those who have achieved continuity (الموالاة) in his worship. *End of the Thirty-First Part.*

(Chapter on Wiping Over the Leather Socks (Al-Khuffayn))

In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful

### [The Difference Among Scholars Regarding Wiping Over the Leather Socks]

As for wiping over the leather socks (الخفين), the scholars of the Sacred Law (الشريعة) differed concerning it. Some say it is permissible absolutely, some say it is absolutely prohibited, such as Ibn Abbas and one narration from Malik, and some say it is permissible during travel (السفر) but not while resident (الحضر).

(Continuation on the Esoteric Ruling in That Regard)

### [Purification (الطهارة) is Transcendent Affirmation (Tanzīh), and The Real (الحق) is the Object of Transcendent Affirmation]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) concerning wiping over the leather socks, know that it is an accidental matter (أمر يعرض) that occurs to a person, and it is difficult for the one to whom it occurs to remove it, just as it is difficult for the wearer to remove the sock. Thus, the ruling of purification (الطهارة) transferred to it, and it was wiped over. Since purification (الطهارة) is transcendent affirmation (تنزيه), and The Real (الحق) is the object intended by the one performing *tanzīh*, as Allah the Exalted said: <<سُبْحَانَ رَبِّكَ رَبِّ الْعِزَّةِ عَمَّا يَصِفُونَ>> (Exalted is your Lord, the Lord of Might, above what they describe). And *al-izza* (Might) means prevention. He mentioned that His Essence (ذاته) is prevented from being a locus for what the atheists (الملحدون) describe Him with.

### [The Transcendent Affirmation (Tanzīh) of Scholars Concerning Allah is Knowledge, Not Action]

The Real (الحق) is transcendent in Essence (منزه الذات) by Himself; He is not made transcendent by the servant's affirmation of His transcendence. Thus, the transcendent affirmation (تنزيه) of scholars concerning Allah, the Exalted, is merely knowledge (علم), not action (عمل). For if the affirmation of transcendence by creation concerning their God were an action, then Allah, the Exalted, who is the Transcendent, would be a locus for the effect of this action. Pay attention to this subtle and beautiful indication. He, the Exalted, does not accept the transcendent affirmation of His servants insofar as they are agents performing an action, for only the ignorant among the servants sees *tanzīh* as an action. The knowledgeable person sees it as knowledge. When he speaks of it, he only speaks by way of definition of what the matter is in itself, which is His saying and His remembrance. The effect of his action is only in his knowledge of the transcendence of his Creator. He brings it out from potentiality to actuality through speech and remembrance. This may then affect the souls of the listeners who did not previously believe that Allah possessed that attribute of transcendence.

### [The Servant (العبد) is a Veil (حجاب) Over The Real (الحق)]

The servant (العبد) is a veil (حجاب) over The Real (الحق), for the outward effects are generally perceived and attributed to the means (الأسباب) established by The Real. This is why the servant says, "I did," "I made," "I fasted," and "I prayed," attributing all his actions to himself, due to his veil from their Creator, who is in him, from him, and who causes them to flow. Just as the leather sock (الخف) became a veil (حجاب) between the person performing ablution and the delivery of the ablution to the foot, and the ruling of purification transferred to the sock, likewise, man's affirmation of the transcendence of his Creator—which is purification (الطهارة) and sanctification (التقديس)—since the effect of that *tanzīh* cannot actually reach The Real (الحق) because He is transcendent by His Essence (ذاته), the ruling of the effect of that *tanzīh* transfers to the affirming human, who is a veil over his Creator, insofar as practical *tanzīh* has an effect on the one affirming transcendence. The human accepted it, just as the sock accepted the purification through the legislated wiping. Thus, the servant is the one who affirms his own transcendence (نزه نفسه) from the ignorance that resides in the soul of the ignorant person who attributes to The Real what is inappropriate for Him and what His Essence does not accept.

### [The Witnessing (مشهد) of One Who Said: 'Glory Be to Me!']

Allah says in the authentic tradition (الخبر الصحيح) that He is the foot of the servant with which he walks. Sensory perception only sees the servant walking with his foot. When he wore the leather sock (الخف), which is the very entity (عين ذات) of the servant, the ruling of purification transferred to it: <<إِنَّمَا هِيَ أَعْمَالُكُمْ تُرَدُّ عَلَيْكُمْ>> (It is only your deeds that are returned to you). Thus, the object of the ruling is the sock. From this perspective comes the permissibility of wiping absolutely, whether traveling (سفرا) or resident (حضر). The state of residency (الحضر) corresponds to the transcendent affirmation (التنزيه) that returns to you, so you say, "Glory be to me (سبحاني)," in this state, as has been transmitted from the men of Allah (رجال الله). The witnessing (مشهد) of the one who said "Glory be to me" was this station we have mentioned. And travel (السفر) is the transcendent affirmation that transfers from your utterance of it in teaching to the ear of the listening student, affecting the listener's soul by the acquisition of that knowledge, thereby purifying his locus.

This measure of transfer from the knowledgeable teacher to the student is called travel (سفرا) because he unveiled (*asfara*) the matter to him through this teaching as it truly is, thus purifying his locus from the ignorance he held regarding that issue. From this perspective also, wearing the leather sock (الخف) and its equivalents, such as the boot (*jurmūq*) and the stocking (*jawrab*), which are worn and customarily cover the area of the foot subject to ablution—And since one of the names for the foot in the language is *al-qadam* (foot/precedence), this strengthens the concept of *qadamiyya* (primordiality/foot-ness) in the foot, because *al-qadam* is used ambiguously in the language, as it expresses permanence or precedence. One says, "So-and-so has a precedence of *qadam* in this matter," meaning he has an ancient, stable foundation in it. Likewise, *al-rijl* (foot/leg) is also used ambiguously in the language; one says, "a *rijl* of locusts," meaning a group or swarm of locusts. If someone says, "The foot is warmed by the sock," it is known with certainty that he means the specific, known organ. Thus, contextual indications (قرائن الأحوال) and the semantic implications of attributes specify what was ambiguous due to shared usage. The ruling of purification transferred to the sock after its object was the foot, but only when the sock is worn, purifying it from whatever might cling to it that prevents purification, both legally and essentially.

### [The Attribution of the Foot (القدم) and Hurrying (الهرولة) to Allah]

Likewise, when the foot (*al-qadam*) was attributed to Allah the Exalted in the hadith, "The Compeller places His foot therein," it might occur to the mind of some rationalists (العقلاء) that the attribution of the foot to Allah the Exalted is not on the same level as its attribution to man or to every creature with a leg and a foot, and that what is meant is, for example, something else. They neglected the feet of the embodied spirits (أقدام المتجسدين من الأرواح). Allah the Exalted removed this misconception from the one who held it by attributing to Himself the hurrying (*al-harwala*), which is speeding up one's walk, following the description of the foot. Thus, The Real (الحق) is with those who walk on two feet, not those who crawl on their bellies, while maintaining the realization that <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). This is necessary.

### [Allah is the Unknown Who is Not Known]

We do not describe Him nor attribute anything to Him except what He attributed to Himself or described Himself with. He only attributed hurrying (*al-harwala*) to Himself so that it might be known that He intended the foot (*al-qadam*) that accepts the attribute and ruling of striving, in a manner befitting His Majesty, because He is the Unknown Who is not known. It cannot be said that He is the indefinite noun that cannot be defined. Allah the Exalted said: <<وَلَا يُحِيطُونَ بِهِ عِلْمًا>> (And they do not encompass Him in knowledge).
