### [The Intelligibility of the Foot (القدم) and Hurrying (الهرولة)]

We do not say that by attributing the foot, He intended what the proponents of transcendent affirmation (المنزهة) specified according to their claim and restricted themselves to. Rather, He brought hurrying (*al-harwala*) to establish the concept of foot-ness (*qadamiyya*) and placed it in the position of the sock (الخف) relative to the foot, in order to remove the perceived ambiguity. Thus, the transcendent affirmation (التنزيه) transferred from the foot to the hurrying. The proponent of *tanzīh* had been preoccupied with affirming the transcendence of the foot, but when hurrying came, the *tanzīh* transferred to it, just as the ruling of the purification of the foot transferred to the sock. So, the servant affirms the transcendence of his Lord from the hurrying customary in common usage, and affirms that it is according to what befits His Majesty, the Exalted. He cannot fail to describe Him with it, since The Real (الحق) knows Himself best and has affirmed this attribute for Himself. Whoever rejects its attribution to Him is not a believer. However, what is obligatory upon him is to refer the knowledge of it to Allah—I mean, the knowledge of the attribution. As for the intelligibility of hurrying, He only addressed the people of the language with what they can comprehend. Hurrying is intelligible, but the form of the attribution is unknown. The same applies to everything He described Himself with that is also used to describe created things.

### [The Permissibility of the Transfer of Purification from One Locus to Another]

The only purpose of what we have mentioned is the permissibility (جواز) of the transfer of purification (الطهارة) from one locus to another due to some correspondence or resemblance. We only stated permissibility, not obligation (الوجوب), for obligation contradicts permissibility. The wearer of the sock has the option to remove his sock and wash his feet according to the Sacred Law, or wipe them with water, according to what his doctrine dictates in that regard, and there is nothing preventing him from doing so. Likewise, this rational person may remain focused on affirming the transcendence of the foot and not transfer to hurrying, removing it from this foot based on what first comes to mind, since it is clear that the attribution of the foot to The Real does not resemble the attribution of our feet to us in all respects. For this reason, obligation was not attached to the wiping; rather, its ruling was permissibility (الجواز).

(Continuation)

As for those who permit it during travel (سفرا) but prohibit it during residency (الحضر): this applies when the transcendent affirmation (التنزيه) is an action, in which case its effect is only upon the listening, receptive student. The *tanzīh* travels from the knowledgeable teacher to the student upon the conveyance of utterance and speech, whether by expression or indication from the teacher to the student.

(Continuation) As for those who prohibited its permissibility absolutely

The reality of transcendent affirmation (التنزيه) belongs only to Allah, the Exalted, for He is the Transcendent by His Essence (ذاته). The servant (العبد) can never be absolutely transcendent, nor is it valid, even if he affirms transcendence from one thing unless he affirms transcendence from another. It is inherent in his reality that he does not accept absolute *tanzīh*. If he possesses this attribute, it is not permissible to affirm his transcendence, for that contradicts knowledge. Accidental matters (الأمور العوارضة) have no effect on Realities (الحقائق). The servant's acceptance of the effects of *tanzīh* indicates a lack of transcendence from accepting effects within himself. This is the reason for prohibiting the absolute permissibility of wiping over the leather sock (الخف) and its equivalents, if you understand.

(Continuation and Completion) As for the symbolism of the two socks

What is meant by them are the two states of existence (النشأتان): the corporeal state (نشأة الجسم) and the spiritual state (نشأة الروح). Each state of existence has the purification (الطهارة) appropriate for it. Understand this.

(Chapter on Defining the Locus of Wiping on the Leather Sock and Its Equivalents)

The scholars of the Sacred Law (الشريعة) differed in defining the wiping on the leather sock. Some say that the obligatory amount is wiping the top of the sock, and anything beyond that is desirable (مستحب), which is wiping the bottom of the sock. Ali ibn Abi Talib (رضي الله عنه) said: "If the religion were based on opinion, the bottom of the sock would be more deserving of wiping than the top. But I saw the Messenger of Allah (صلى الله عليه وسلم) wipe the top of the sock." Some say it is obligatory to wipe both their tops and bottoms. Some say it is obligatory to wipe only their tops, and the proponent of this view does not recommend wiping their bottoms. And some say that the obligatory part is wiping the bottom of the sock, and wiping the top is desirable—this is the view of Ashhab.

(Continuation on the Esoteric Ruling in That Regard)

### [The Transcendent Affirmation (Tanzīh), Which is Purification (الطهارة), Relates Either to The Real (الحق) or to the Servant (العبد)]

Know that the Transcendence (التنزيه), which is expressed here by the purification of wiping (*al-masḥ*), relates either to The Real (الحق), as we previously established, or to the servant (العبد) who performs the act of transcendence. The division is restricted, for there is nothing there except servant and Lord, Creator and created.

In this matter, we have the terms "upper" and "lower." The attribute of loftiness (*al-'uluw*) belongs to Allah the Exalted, because He is the Exalter of Ranks (رَفِيعُ الدَّرَجاتِ) by His Essence (ذاته). He, the Exalted, said: <<سَبِّحِ اسْمَ رَبِّكَ الْأَعْلَى>> (Glorify the Name of your Lord, the Most High). Nothing in the Quran is more closely related to the wiping of the upper part of the sock/boot (*al-khuff*) than this verse.

And the lower part (*al-sufl*) belongs to us. Likewise, the outer (ظاهر) and inner (باطن) parts of the sock/boot—meaning these two terms—The Real (الحق) may have the ruling of the Manifest (الظاهر) and the Hidden (الباطن). Or, the ruling of the Manifest may belong to Him in the breaking of customs (خرق العوائد), and the ruling of the Hidden may belong to Him in the customs themselves (نفس العوائد), which constitute the majority of the signs pointing to Allah <<لِقَوْمٍ يَعْقِلُونَ>> (for a people who reason).

### [Levels of Transcendence: The Highest Transcendence, Glory be to Him]

Sometimes, Transcendence (التنزيه) is truly attached to the Most High (الأعلى), Glory and Exaltation be to Him, and this is the limit of what is obligatory (*al-wājib*) concerning it. It is recommended (يستحب) to apply Transcendence to the servant (العبد) insofar as his action returns to him. This follows the doctrine of those who hold that wiping the upper part of the sock/boot is obligatory and wiping the lower part is recommended.

### [Transcendence through The Real, Manifest and Hidden]

And sometimes, Transcendence is attached to The Real (الحق), Glory be to Him, both Manifest (ظاهرا) and Hidden (باطنا). This belongs to the one who sees nothing in Existence (الوجود) but Allah, due to the overwhelming dominance of Witnessing (المشاهدة) and Theophanies (التجليات) upon him. He sees The Real as Manifest and Hidden, so no act of Transcendence proceeds from him except upon The Real, Glory be to Him. Transcendence is a non-existent relation (نسبة عدمية), not an existent one (وجودية). This is the view that mandates wiping both the outer and inner surfaces of the socks/boots.

### [Transcendence through Allah the Exalted due to His Perfection in His Essence]

And sometimes, Transcendence is attached to Allah the Exalted due to His perfection in His Essence (ذاته). It is not recommended to apply Transcendence to Creation (الخلق) due to the inherent deficiency (النقص الذاتي) that belongs to them; one would fall into falsehood if he applied it. He sees that if the contingent being (الممكن) were to be transcendent one day, in any respect, due to an attribute of perfection it possessed, it would, by virtue of that attribute, be independent of Allah and an equal to Him. It is impossible for Creation to possess an attribute by which they are independent of Allah, for they are poor <<إِلَى الله>> (unto Allah) in all respects, and <<وَاللهُ هُوَ الْغَنِيُّ الْحَمِيدُ>> (and Allah is the Self-Sufficient, the Praiseworthy).

Therefore, this view prohibits the recommendation of wiping the lower part of the sock/boot, stating that there is no Transcendent (منزه) except Allah, the Most High, Who is Manifest (الظاهر) to His servants through the attributes of Majesty (نعوت الجلال). This, as we said, is the doctrine of those who hold that wiping the upper part of the sock/boot is mandatory and wiping the lower part is not recommended.

### [The Obligation of Transcendence from the Name The Hidden]

And sometimes, Transcendence—meaning its obligation (وجوبه)—is attached to His Name The Hidden (الباطن). He says that The Hidden is a locus where it is difficult to discover the attributes of Majesty (نعوت الجلال) that He deserves, due to His hiddenness. Thus, it is obligatory to apply Transcendence to The Real (الحق) in His Name The Hidden, removing the effect of the veil (الحجاب) that decreed Him to be hidden and unknowable. Yet, Allah is too High and too Glorious to be encompassed by a veil. Therefore, Transcendence is obligatory from the perspective of His Name The Hidden. This is the reasoning of those, like Ashhab, who mandated wiping the inner part of the sock/boot and recommended wiping the upper part, which corresponds to the Name The Manifest (الاسم الظاهر).

### [The Recommendation of Transcendence from the Name The Manifest]

He says: And it is recommended to apply Transcendence to The Real (الحق) in His Name The Manifest (الاسم الظاهر), which is His Theophany (تجليه) in form (الصورة) to His servants. He is thus transcended from being restricted by that form, yet it is a Transcendence that does not remove Him from the Knowledge (العلم) that He is the very essence (عين) of that form. For He knows Himself better than the intellect (العقل) knows Him, and better than any other knower knows Him. He has said of Himself that He is the One Who manifests Himself to His servants in that form, as mentioned by Muslim in his *Sahih*.

His Transcendence (تنزيهه) in this context is that He is not confined by a form—meaning no form confines Him—but rather He manifests (يتجلى) in whatever form He chooses to appear to His servants. Based on this Reality (الحقيقة) that He is in Himself, He mentioned concerning our creation, after shaping and perfecting us, that He assembled us in whatever form He willed. Similarly, He manifests Himself to His servants in whatever form He wills. Here is a divine secret (سر إلهي) upon which I alert you so that you may know Him by it. The proponent of this doctrine recommends transcending Him in His manifestation (ظهوره) from the permanence of the Theophany (التجلي) in that specific form, by dwelling therein in your perception. Understand this. This is the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) regarding the determination of the locus.

(Chapter on the Type of Locus for Wiping, which is what covers the foot, whether a sock/boot or a stocking)

### [The Difference of Opinion among Jurists regarding wiping the stockings]

Know that those who permit wiping the socks/boots (الخفين) agree on wiping them without doubt. They differed regarding wiping the stockings (الجوربين). Some prohibit it absolutely, some permit it absolutely, and some permit it only if it possesses a specific quality: either that it is so dense and thick that the water of the wiping does not reach the foot, or that it is lined with leather that permits walking in it—meaning, that it is possible to walk in it.

(Continuation: Its Esoteric Ruling)

### [The Servant is a Veil before his Creator]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) on this, it has been previously discussed regarding the sock/boot (الخف). The ruling concerning the stocking (الجورب) remains. It is established that the stocking is like the sock/boot in its veiling quality (الصفة الحجابية), for the servant (العبد) is a veil (حجاب) before his Creator. This is why the saying came: "Whoever knows himself knows his Lord," for the self is the proof (الدليل) of Him. Although the proof and the proven (الدليل والمدلول) are connected in a specific way, they are opposites that do not combine.

### [The Saint, when seen, reminds one of Allah]

We previously stated that the term *khuff* (sock/boot) is a stronger indicator of the foot in removing ambiguity than the word *rijl* (foot/man) applied to it, and likewise with *harwala* (trotting/hastening). That has passed. However, the stocking (الجورب), although it covers the foot, does not possess the strength of the sock/boot due to its permeability (التخلل). Water penetrates and permeates its pores quickly, which is not the case with the sock/boot. Its esoteric ruling is that among the servants of Allah, there are those who are stronger in indicating Allah than others. Such a person is in the position of the stocking, as established in the tradition concerning Allah's description of His saints (أولياء الله).

More than one person narrated to me, from one who narrated to him, reaching the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that it was said to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, "O Messenger of Allah, who are the saints of Allah?" The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, replied: "Those who, when they are seen, Allah is remembered." Al-Hafiz Abu Nu'aym mentioned this in his book *Hilyat al-Awliya*.

This is due to what we mentioned: the strength of their indication of Allah the Exalted, which is visible upon them, stemming from their intense devotion to His remembrance, Glory be to Him, and the humility, obedience, and constant need (الافتقار) they maintain toward Allah with every breath. If people wish to apply Transcendence (تنزيه) to them, they cannot achieve their transcendence except by transcending Allah, for they only remember them through Allah, due to the sincere spiritual states (أحوالهم الصادقة) granted to them by Allah.

### [The Malamati: A Sock/Boot or Stocking Lined with Leather]

If the sock/boot is lined with leather, it represents the Malamati (الملامتي), who conceals himself and his spiritual state (حاله) with Allah from the lower world (العالم السفلي), preventing them from perceiving the degree of his sainthood (ولايته) with Allah. This is analogous to how the stocking is concealed from the earth, preventing the earth from reaching and affecting it, by the leather that intervenes between the earth and the stocking. This leather represents the permissible actions (المباحات) by which the Malamati conceals himself from the veiled lower world (العالم الأسفل المحجوب). They perceive nothing of him except that attribute by which he is indistinguishable from the common believers. Yet, behind that attribute, he stands in the station of sainthood (مقام الولاية) with Allah. The upper part of the stocking remains, on the side of the Most High, with Allah, Glory be to Him, without any barrier (حائل) between him and his Lord, the Mighty and Majestic.

### [The Consideration: Passing from the Form to what corresponds to it in your Essence]

I have opened for you the door of consideration (*i'tibar*) legally (شرعا), which is the passage (الجواز) from the form (الصورة) whose ruling appeared in the senses (الحس) to what corresponds to it in your essence (ذاتك) or in the presence of The Real (جناب الحق), indicating The Real. This is the meaning of consideration (*i'tibar*), for it derives from crossing (*'abarta*) the valley, meaning you traversed and passed through it.

(Chapter on the Description of what is Wiped)

### [The Difference of Opinion regarding the permissibility of wiping a torn sock/boot]

Those who permit wiping agree unanimously on the permissibility of wiping a sound sock/boot. They differed regarding a torn one (المخرق). Some permit it if the tear is minor, without setting a limit. Some limit the minor tear to three fingers. Some permit it as long as the name "sock/boot" still applies to it, even if the tear is excessive, and this is the most reasonable view to me. Others prohibit wiping if the tear is in the front of the sock/boot, even if minor. What I hold is that this issue has no basis (أصل) and no explicit text (*naṣṣ*) concerning it in the Book or the Sunna. It would be better to disregard it and not occupy ourselves with it. However, since the jurists of the Sharia (علماء الشريعة) have differed on it, necessitating discussion, the truth, in our view, lies with those who say it is permissible as long as it is still called a sock/boot.

(Continuation: The Esoteric Ruling on that)

### [The Hidden is the Manifest]

This is to say that the *khuff* (sock/boot) was named *khuff* from *khifā’* (concealment) because it absolutely covers the foot. If it is torn and something of the foot appears, one wipes what has appeared and wipes the sock/boot, provided that the condition that it is still called a sock/boot is met. There is a marvelous secret (سر عجيب) in this for the perceptive and correct individual: that the Hidden (الخافي) is also the Manifest (الظاهر). Imru’ al-Qays says:

*خفاهن من أنفاقهن*
(He concealed them from their holes)

meaning, he brought them out and made them manifest.

### [The Exoteric Aspect of Sharia is a Veil over the Reality of the Ruling of Unity]

We only mandated wiping what appeared because we were commanded in the Book of Allah to wipe the feet; thus, if it appears, we wipe it. As for the esoteric aspect (الباطن), the exoteric aspect of the Sharia (ظاهر الشريعة) is a veil (ستر) over the reality of the ruling of Unity (حكم التوحيد), by attributing everything to Allah. The purification (الطهارة) in the Sharia is related to Unity (التوحيد) accompanying it, by seeing it as Allah’s ruling upon His Creation, not the ruling of the created, such as judicial policies.

### [The Law is Allah's Ruling, not the Intellect's Ruling]

The Law (الشرع) is Allah’s ruling, not the intellect’s ruling (حكم العقل), as some see it. The purification of the Sharia is seeing it as coming from Allah, the One, The Real (الحق). Therefore, we should not impugn the ruling of a jurist (مجتهد), because the Law, which is Allah’s ruling, has established that judgment; thus, it is Allah’s Law by His confirmation of it. This is an issue where all proponents of the schools of law fall into error, due to their failure to keep in mind what we have pointed out, despite knowing it. They neglected to recall it and thus behaved improperly (أساءوا الأدب) toward Allah in this matter, while the well-mannered (الأدباء) servants of Allah succeeded in it. Whoever faults a specific jurist has faulted The Real (الحق) in what He established as a ruling.

### [Faulting the doctrine of attributing all actions to Allah in all respects]

If the Law (الشرع) is torn, and in a certain matter, a ruling of Unity (التوحيد) appears that absolutely removes the ruling of the Law, the ruling of purification shifts to that Unity which affects the removal of the Sharia ruling. This is like someone who attributes all actions to Allah in all respects, caring nothing for whether what appears from him is a transgression or a compliance. Such Unity (التوحيد) must be transcended (التنزيه منه) due to the appearance of this effect, for it is a tearing of the Sharia and a removal of Allah’s ruling, just as wiping is not permissible when the name "sock/boot" is removed. If the tear allows the name "sock/boot" to remain, the ruling is as we established: wiping the sock/boot and wiping what appeared of the foot. This means clarifying the lawful aspect (الوجه المشروع) in that specific Unity concerning this issue, which is to say: <<وَاللهُ خَلَقَكُمْ وَمَا تَعْمَلُونَ>> (And Allah created you and what you do). Actions are created by Allah while being attributed to us. Thus, He did not attribute them in all respects, so it did not affect the wiping, and the ruling remains as we established.

### [The Appearance of Unity in Three Stations]

The people of our path (أهل طريقنا) differed greatly on this issue, exactly mirroring the difference among those who permit wiping the sock/boot. As for those who limited the tear to three fingers, they observed the appearance of Unity (التوحيد) in three stations (منازل): the ruling of the Law (حكم الشرع) in man regarding his meaning, his senses, and his imagination (خياله). If Unity encompasses these three, it is not permissible to adopt it, and one shifts to wiping or washing the foot, just as a person shifts his self-transcendence away from such Unity when it removes the ruling of the Law from him, thus taking the ruling of one from whom the name "sock/boot" has been removed.

(Chapter on the Time Limit for Wiping)

### [The Difference of Opinion among Jurists regarding the Time Limit for Wiping]

There was a difference of opinion on this. Some held a time limit: three days and nights for the traveler (المسافر) and one day and night for the resident (المقيم). Others held that there is no time limit, and one may wipe as long as he wishes, provided no impediment, such as ritual impurity requiring a full bath (الجنابة), arises.

(Continuation: Its Esoteric Ruling)

### [The Meaning of the Traveler Wiping for Three Days and Nights]

As for the esoteric ruling (الحكم في الباطن) on this, according to the doctrine of those who hold a time limit: We established in the chapter on the Knower and the Learner (العالم والمتعلم) concerning wiping the sock/boot that this is a journey (سفر), as the matter moves from the teacher (المعلم) to the learner (المتعلم). The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, when teaching people their laws (شرائعهم), would repeat the word three times so that it would be understood from him, because he was commanded with clarification and conveyance. This is the meaning of the traveler wiping three times.

### [The Time Limit for the Resident: One Day and Night]

As for the time limit for the resident (الحاضر) being one day and night, this is because he only needs that matter to be established within himself so that he knows it, and he does not repeat it for himself because it has already manifested to him, and he is certain of it within himself. However, he is not certain of others accepting it when teaching, so he repeats it three times to ensure that it has been understood from him.

### [The Meaning of No Time Limit for Wiping]

Those who did not hold to a specific limit considered the natural dispositions of the learners (فطر المتعلمين). Some understand immediately, while others only understand after elaboration and repeated repetition until they grasp it. Thus, they do not set a specific number when teaching others, which is analogous to travel (السفر). Nor do they limit it for themselves, which is analogous to residence (الحضر), for within himself, he might imagine that what has appeared to him could be a doubt (شبهة), so he investigates it repeatedly. Hence, there is no time limit.

### [Janaba is Estrangement, and the Junub is the Stranger]

As for the ruling of *janaba* (major ritual impurity) regarding the removal of the sock/boot: *Janaba* is estrangement (الغربة), and the *junub* (one in a state of *janaba*) is the stranger (الغريب). If a strange matter occurs in the heart that impugns the Law (الشرع), one must investigate it purely by the intellect (العقل), without relying on the Law for evidence. An example is the thought of the Brahmin who denies the Sharia (البرهمى المنكر للشريعة) crossing his mind. He cannot accept the evidence of the Law to invalidate this thought that occurred to him, because that is the point of contention. He must necessarily shift from relying on the evidence of the Law to relying on what the proofs of rational investigation (أدلة النظر) provide. This applies whether it occurs to him personally, like the resident (الحضر), or to others, like the traveler (السفر), just as the *junub*, whether traveling or resident, must remove the sock/boot.

(Chapter on the Condition for Wiping the Socks/Boots)

### [The Difference of Opinion among Jurists regarding the Condition for Wiping the Socks/Boots]

Some hold that a condition for wiping is that the feet must be purified by the ablution (*wuḍū’*) purification. Others hold that the only condition is their purification from ritual impurity (*najasa*), and this is what I hold, though the first opinion is more cautious. Another condition remains: that one sock/boot is not worn over another. Some permit wiping both, and this is what I hold, while others prohibit it. The ruling for the *jurmūq* (overshoe) is similar.

(Continuation: The Esoteric Ruling on that)

### [Transcending The Real from Harwala is denying what He described Himself with]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) on this: The purification (الطهر) understood esoterically is Transcendence (التنزيه), as we established rationally and legally. This specific purification of the feet is a legal purification (طهارة شرعية). Allah the Exalted described Himself as having *harwala* (trotting/hastening) for the one who approaches Him striving. Striving (*sa'y*) and *harwala* are attributes of the feet. Whoever transcends The Real (الحق) from *harwala* has denied The Real in what He described Himself with. Although the intellect (العقل), based on its evidence, does not accept this attribution to the Exalted, faith (الإيمان) accepts it and negates anthropomorphism (*tashbīh*) by His saying, <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him), and by rational proof.

### [The Divine Harwala in the view of Faith and the view of the Intellect]

The Divine *harwala* should not be interpreted (تأول) as the intensification or confirmation of the Divine approach toward the servant, nor by other types of transcendent interpretations (التأويلات المنزهة). Rather, those rational people who interpreted it did so as the multiplication of the Divine approach with abundant reward (جزيل الثواب) for the servant when he comes striving to his Lord through acts of worship that involve walking, such as striving to the mosques, striving in the circumambulation (*ṭawāf*) and toward it, striving to the Hajj, visiting the sick, fulfilling people's needs, and accompanying funerals—any act of worship involving striving, whether its location is near or far. The Exalted said: <<يَا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا إِذَا نُودِيَ لِلصَّلَاةِ مِنْ يَوْمِ الْجُمُعَةِ فَاسْعَوْا إِلَى ذِكْرِ اللهِ>> (O you who have believed, when the call to prayer is announced on the day of Friday, then proceed earnestly to the remembrance of Allah).

### [Transcending The Real is not removing what He described Himself with]

The purification of ablution (طهر الوضوء) is the description of The Real (الحق) as trotting (*harwala*). The purification that is cleanliness (النظافة) is the Transcendence (تنزيه) of The Real, which is not removing from Him what He described Himself with. As for what He did not describe Himself with, which are attributes of contingent beings (نعوت الممكنات), transcending Him from being described by any of that belongs to the intellect (العقل). The intellect is subject to the ruling of the Law (الشرع). If the Law speaks concerning the attributes of The Real, the intellect, if it is believing, cannot reject that. The described attribute is either possibly acceptable or its acceptability is unknown. Thus, the intellect is obliged to accept the legally prescribed description, even if the acceptability of the Described is unknown to it. For this reason, regarding the purification of the feet, we adopted the linguistic purification (الطهر اللغوي), which is cleanliness and transcendence from impurity (*najasa*). Therefore, we are not bound by any of the subsidiary issues arising from this matter according to the doctrine of those who hold to the ablution purification. As for wearing a sock/boot over a sock/boot, this is The Real describing Himself with *harwala*. *Harwala* is an attribute of striving (*sa'y*), and striving is an attribute of the foot. Striving may involve *harwala* or it may not. If this is the case, *harwala* is an attribute of striving, and between *harwala* and the foot there is another matter, which is striving. This is like the sock/boot over the sock/boot, and discussion on this has preceded. Understand this.

(Chapter on Knowing what Nullifies the Purification of Wiping the Sock/Boot)

### [What is Agreed Upon and What is Disputed]

There is agreement that its nullifiers are all the nullifiers of ablution (وضوء), and its chapter will follow later in this section. Scholars differed on whether removing the sock/boot nullifies the purification (الطهارة). Some say the entire purification is invalidated, and one must renew the ablution. Some say only the purification of the feet is invalidated, so one must wash them, subject to the previous difference regarding continuity (*muwālāt*). Others say removing the sock/boot does not affect the purification of the foot, and this is what I hold, although renewing the ablution is more cautious. It does not affect the entire purification unless an event occurs that nullifies it, as will follow.

(Continuation: The Esoteric Ruling on that)

### [The General Spread of Transcendence in the Described]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) concerning those who say the entire purification is invalidated: This is the spread of Transcendence (التنزيه) throughout the Described. If He accepts a specific transcendence, He accepts all other aspects of transcendence that are rationally understood in Him. Likewise, if a certain transcendence is invalidated concerning the Described, the invalidation spreads to all attributes of transcendence.

### [The Law Negating a Specific Attribute from The Real]

As for those who say only the purification of the foot is invalidated: This is when the Law (الشرع) removes a specific attribute from The Real (الحق) by designation. This does not necessitate the removal of every attribute that implies anthropomorphism (*tashbīh*). For Allah, Glory be to Him, transcended Himself from begetting (أن يلد), but He did not transcend Himself from hesitation regarding a matter He intends to do, nor did He transcend Himself from deliberation, nor did He transcend Himself from anger.

### [Negating Material Begetting from Allah, not Selection, which is Spiritual Begetting]

As for those who say he remains purified, and removing the sock/boot has no ruling or effect on the purification he possessed while wearing it: He says that even though The Real (الحق) transcended Himself from begetting, the attribute remains for Him, for He said: <<لَوْ أَرَادَ اللهُ أَنْ يَتَّخِذَ وَلَدًا لَاصْطَفَى مِمَّا يَخْلُقُ مَا يَشَاءُ>> (If Allah had intended to take a son, He could have chosen from what He creates whatever He willed). Thus, He maintained the matter under His ruling by His saying, "If Allah had intended." This is similar to His saying, <<لَوْلَا كِتَابٌ مِنَ اللهِ سَبَقَ>> (If not for a decree from Allah that preceded), and His saying, <<مَا يُبَدَّلُ الْقَوْلُ لَدَيَّ>> (The word will not be changed with Me). This is a refutation of those who say that the Deity, by His Essence (ذاته), brought the contingent being into existence, without relation to Will (إرادة) or prior Knowledge (علم). The correct view is what the Lawgiver (الشارع) stated, even if that relation is not an additional existent matter. Know this.

(Chapters on Waters)

### [The Rulings of Waters, Exoteric and Esoteric]

Discussion has already preceded at the beginning of the chapter regarding the difference between rainwater and spring water, and we clarified what is sufficient therein. In these chapters, let us mention the ruling that the jurists of the Sharia (علماء الشريعة) inclined toward in the exoteric aspect (الظاهر), along with what corresponds to it in the purification of the esoteric aspect (طهارة الباطن).

(Chapter on Absolute Waters)

### [What the Jurists Agreed Upon Regarding Waters and What They Differed On]

Scholars agreed that all waters are pure in themselves and purifying for others, except seawater, concerning which there is a difference of opinion. They also agreed that whatever changes the water, but is usually inseparable from it, does not remove its purifying quality, except for stagnant water (*al-mā’ al-ājin*), concerning which Ibn Sirin differed. My view is that everything to which the name "water" applies absolutely is pure and purifying, whether it is seawater or stagnant water. They also agreed that water whose color, taste, smell, or all of these attributes have been changed by impurity (*najāsa*) is not permissible for purification. If the water and none of its attributes are changed, it remains upon its original state of purity and purification, and the impurity that fell into it does not affect it. However, I know of a difference of opinion on this matter regarding a small amount of water into which a small amount of impurity falls, such that none of its attributes are changed.

(Continuation: The Esoteric Ruling on that)

### [Water is the Life by which Hearts are Revived]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) on what we mentioned: Know that water is the life (الحياة) by which hearts (القلوب) are revived, and through it, purification from ignorance (الجهل) is achieved for every heart. The Exalted said: <<أَوَمَنْ كَانَ مَيْتًا فَأَحْيَيْنَاهُ وَجَعَلْنَا لَهُ نُورًا يَمْشِي بِهِ فِي النَّاسِ كَمَنْ مَثَلُهُ فِي الظُّلُمَاتِ لَيْسَ بِخَارِجٍ مِنْهَا>> (Is he who was dead and We gave him life and made for him a light by which to walk among the people like one who is in darknesses, never to emerge therefrom?). This is a parable concerning disbelief and faith, and knowledge and ignorance.

### [Seawater is Created from the Attribute of Divine Wrath]

As for seawater, concerning which the rare difference of opinion occurred: It is created from the attribute of Wrath (صفة الغضب). Wrath results in expulsion and distance for the one upon whom wrath falls, while purification leads to proximity and connection (الوصلة). This is the reason for the esoteric difference of opinion. As for the exoteric reason, it is the change in taste. Whoever holds that wrath for Allah leads to proximity to Allah and connection with Him permits ablution with seawater, and this is the view I adopt.

### [Expansion in the Science of Unity and Adherence to Legal Propriety]

Whoever has expanded in the science of Unity (علم التوحيد) but does not adhere to legal propriety (الأدب الشرعي)—so he does not become angry for Allah or for himself—does not permit ablution with seawater, because it is created from Wrath. He fears that it might instill wrath in him, causing the attribute of wrath to subsist in him, which his spiritual state (حاله) does not allow. For Unity prevents him from anger, because in his view, there is no one upon whom to be angry, due to the Oneness of the Essence (*aḥadiyyat al-'ayn*) in all actions attributed to the cosmos. If he had someone upon whom to be angry, there would be no Unity. The cause of wrath is only the action, and there is no actor but Allah. This issue is one of the most difficult for the people (Sufis), although it is easy for us, due to our knowledge of the loci of Divine Propriety (الأدب الإلهي) that He legislated for us, followed by the assumption of Divine characteristics (التخلق بالأخلاق الإلهية), among which is Wrath, which He described Himself with in His Book. The Exalted said: <<وَغَضِبَ اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَلَعَنَهُ>> (and the Wrath of Allah is upon him and His curse), and His saying in the verse of mutual cursing (*li'an*): <<وَالْخَامِسَةَ أَنَّ غَضَبَ اللهِ عَلَيْهَا>> (and the fifth [testimony] is that the Wrath of Allah be upon her). The Sunna also states that Allah will be angry on the Day of Resurrection with a wrath unlike any He was angry with before, and unlike any He will be angry with after.

### [The Well-Mannered is the one who pauses without judgment until the one who has the authority judges]

This person who does not become angry sees nothing but Allah, and his spiritual state (حاله) dictates his judgment. This is the station of perplexity (*ḥayra*). Woe to him if he becomes angry here, and woe to him if he does not become angry in the Hereafter. He is refuted in every state, both in this world and the next. Wrath for Allah is safer, more salvific, and better for man, for it entails adherence to the prescribed propriety (الأدب المشروع). Since wrath is inherent in man's original nature, like cowardice, greed, and avidity, The Real clarified its outlets when it occurs in the servant and he is characterized by it. There are loci and occasions for submission (*taslīm*) that have been legislated, which the well-mannered (الأدباء) adhere to immediately, while the people of spiritual states (أصحاب الأحوال) miss them. There are also loci and occasions for non-submission that have been legislated. The well-mannered person (الأديب) is the one who pauses without judgment until the Lawgiver (الشارع), The Real, judges, and <<وَهُوَ خَيْرُ الْحَاكِمِينَ>> (He is the best of judges). When He judges, the well-mannered person stops where He judged, neither adding nor subtracting.

### [Wrath subsisting in the Soul and Mercy present in the Heart]

Wrath (الغضب) is an esoteric attribute in man that may or may not have an exoteric effect, for the spiritual state (*ḥāl*) is usually dominant, and spiritual states overpower and dominate one another in those in whom they subsist. If one combines the presence of mercy toward the object of wrath in his heart with the ruling of wrath for Allah in his senses and exoteric aspect, then the people of Allah's path (أهل طريق الله) have considered which of the two ways is higher and more rightful. Some of us said that the wrath subsisting in the soul (النفس) is higher, and some of us said that the presence of mercy in the heart and the outward application of the ruling of wrath for Allah is higher.

### [The Servant is compelled in his choice]

The servant (العبد) has no control over this; rather, the servant is directed. He acts according to what is established in him and what is returned to him. Man has no action in his leaving or not leaving a thing; rather, he is compelled in his choice (مجبور في اختياره) if he is a believer. We restricted wrath to be for Allah. As for wrath for other than Allah, human nature (الطبع البشري) necessitates wrath and pleasure.

The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "I am only a human being; I become angry as humans become angry, and I am pleased as humans are pleased." We have learned a spiritual state (*ḥāl*) and a characteristic (*khuluq*) through this hadith. Praise be to Allah for that.

### [Living Water and the Natural Temperament that affects it]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) concerning stagnant water (*al-mā’ al-ājin*), distinct from other things that usually change water but are inseparable from it: Know that Allah, Glory be to Him, did not transcend water from anything that changes it but is usually inseparable from it, except for stagnant water. The Exalted said, describing the inhabitants of Paradise, which is characterized by purity: <<فِيهَا أَنْهَارٌ مِنْ مَاءٍ غَيْرِ آسِنٍ>> (In it are rivers of water, unstagnant). Water is said to be *āsin* or *ājin* when it changes, and it is water stored in cisterns. All stored water changes due to prolonged duration. If the Knowledge (العلم) by which hearts are revived is affected by something from the natural temperament (المزاج الطبيعي), it influences it. For example, the knowledge that Allah is Merciful: when the servant sees Allah's mercy toward His servants as he perceives it in himself—from the tenderness and compassion whose pain he finds within himself—and he seeks to remove that pain he finds in himself by showing mercy to this created being upon whom mercy has fallen, he rises up with tenderness toward him and projects this onto Allah's Mercy. Thus, Allah's Mercy changes in his perception by analogy with his own mercy. It is therefore improper for him to purify himself for the worship of his Lord using such Divine Mercy, which has been changed in his perception. The reason for this is that The Real (الحق) did not describe Himself with tenderness (*riqqa*) in His Mercy. The Real says to you here: Do not let your nature rule over your Divine life. Whoever permits ablution with stagnant water makes no distinction, for The Real has described Himself in places with what human nature (الطبع البشري) necessitates, so everything proceeds in the same manner. The preferable approach is what we mentioned first: that we do not add anything to Allah's ruling concerning what He mentioned about Himself.

### [The Knowledge in whose Ocean Doubts Dissolve]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) concerning limited knowledge (العلم القليل) when misleading doubts (*shubah*) arise and cause change in it: It is not permissible for him to use that knowledge, for he does not trust it. Even if he knows that this knowledge has an aspect leading to The Real (الحق), his weak knowledge prevents him from identifying that specific aspect. He must then turn to the Knowledge (العلم) that consumes doubts, which is the knowledge he derives from faith (الإيمان) through the path of the Law (الشرع) and acting upon it. This is the vast knowledge that does not accept doubts, because it transforms the very essence of the doubt by the true aspect it carries, placing it in its proper context. Thus, it becomes knowledge after having been ignorance by virtue of being a doubt.

### [The Light of Faith in which the Lights of Knowledges are Contained]

The light of faith (نور الإيمان) contains the lights of knowledges (أنوار العلوم), just as the lights of the stars are contained within the light of the sun. Its path is also clear in transforming doubts back into knowledge, because it removes their ruling and shows him, through the light of faith, the true aspect within them. He then sees them as non-existence (*'adam*), and non-existence has no trace or effect in Being (الوجود). Know this. And know that the light of faith here is an expression for the command of the Law (أمر الشرع): meaning, adhere to what I have told you and commanded you, whether you find rational proof for it or not. Examples include believing in the Divine Presence (الجناب الإلهي) in *harwala*, laughter, smiling, and wonder, without asking "how" (*takyeef*) or anthropomorphism (*tashbīh*), even though these are rationally understood from the language. However, we are ignorant of the relation, relying on His saying, <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). This verse is a foundation for Transcendence (التنزيه) for its adherents and a foundation for Anthropomorphism (*tashbīh*) for its adherents.

(Chapter on Water Mixed with Impurity that did not Change any of its Attributes)

### [The Difference of Opinion among Scholars regarding Water Mixed with Impurity that did not Change any of its Attributes]

The jurists of the Sharia (علماء الشريعة) differed concerning water mixed with impurity (*najāsa*) that did not change any of its attributes. Some say it is pure (*ṭāhir*) and purifying (*muṭahhir*), whether little or much, and this is what I hold. However, I say it is purifying but not pure in itself, because we know definitively that impurity mixed with it, but the Law (الشرع) overlooked it. I do not know of anyone else holding this specific view, yet it is rational. We have no legal proof (*dalīl*) that it is pure in itself, only that it is purifying (*ṭahūr*). If they argue against us by citing that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Allah created water purifying; nothing makes it impure," we reply that he did not say it is pure in itself, but rather that it is purifying (*ṭahūr*). And *ṭahūr* is the water and dust that purifies others.

### [Water is Pure in Itself]

As we said, we know definitively that water rationally carries impurity (*najāsa*), but the Lawgiver (الشارع) did not assign an effect to it regarding man's purification with it, nor did He call it impure. The Lawgiver may intend to define the reality of the matter, which is that water in itself is always pure in every respect; no ruling of impurity has ever been passed upon it. That is, impurity is not an attribute of water; rather, the particles of the impure substance merely neighbor its particles. Since it is difficult to separate the particles of urine, for example, from the particles of water, and the particles of impurity became numerous relative to the particles of water, changing one of its attributes, ablution with it was legally prohibited according to the limit recognized in the Law. If the particles of water dominate the particles of impurity, and none of its attributes change, the Lawgiver did not take them into account, nor did He assign a ruling to them regarding purification with it. We know definitively that the one performing purification used water and impurity together in his legal purification. The ruling regarding the use of things belongs to the Law, not the intellect. No legal text ever stated that water is pure and contains no impurity, except by considering what we mentioned about the non-interpenetration of substances, which is a rational matter. What remains is merely their adjacency. The Law considered this adjacency in one instance and disregarded it in another. Therefore, purification was not permitted in the instance where it was considered, and it was permitted in the instance where it was disregarded, but He did not say that it contains no impurity.

### [The Four Rulings of Waters]

The ruling concerning water, based on what we mentioned, falls into four levels, whether impurity mixed with it or not: a ruling that it is pure and purifying; a ruling that it is pure but not purifying; a ruling that it is neither purifying nor pure; and a ruling that it is purifying but not pure. The pure and purifying water is that which no impurity mixed with. The pure but not purifying water is that which is mixed with something not impure, such that it removes the name "absolute water" from it, such as saffron water and the like. The ruling that it is neither pure nor purifying is for water whose attributes have been changed by impurity. The proponent of this ruling refutes the hadith used against us, for the Lawgiver said, "Nothing makes it impure." How then did this arguer consider it here, yet not consider it in the aspect we adopted, that it is purifying but not pure? This necessarily binds him, and he has no legal proof to refute it. The fourth ruling is purifying but not pure, which is the section we are currently discussing: water mixed with impurity that did not change any of its attributes. Some hold a distinction between little and much water, saying that if it is much, it is not impure, but if it is little, it is impure. They did not set a limit for this, but said it becomes impure even if none of its attributes change.

### [The Difference of Opinion regarding the Limit of Little and Much Water]

Then these scholars differed regarding the limit between little and much. The difference concerning the limit itself is well-known in the schools of law, not in sound legal text (*naṣṣ al-shar' al-ṣaḥīḥ*), for the hadiths on this matter have been discussed, such as the hadith of the two *qullahs* (large jars) and the hadith of forty *qullahs*. Then there is the difference among them regarding the definition of the *qullah*. Many subsidiary issues branch off from this chapter, such as water flowing onto impurity, impurity falling into water, and urinating into standing water, and so on. People have many doctrines concerning these matters, but this book is not the place for them, as we did not intend to exhaust all the rulings related to this purification by detailing subsidiary issues. Rather, the intention is to cover the main points for the sake of consideration (*i'tibar*) through the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن). We have dedicated about eighty chapters to this topic, which we will mention, God willing, chapter by chapter. I shall do the same, God willing, for the rest of the acts of worship we resolved to mention in this book: prayer, *zakāt*, fasting, and Hajj. Allah is the Supporter; there is no Lord but Him.

(Continuation: The Esoteric Ruling [Divine Transcendental Knowledge when mixed with the Knowledge of Attributes that suggests Anthropomorphism])

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) concerning what we mentioned in this chapter—water mixed with impurity that did not change any of its attributes—it is the Divine Knowledge (العلم الإلهي) that necessitates Transcendence (التنزيه) from human attributes. If this knowledge is mixed with the knowledge of Attributes (علم الصفات) that suggests a resemblance between Him and His Creation, and this causes a kind of confusion in the soul of the knower, that amount of knowledge of the attributes that cause commonality is consumed within the knowledge that necessitates Transcendence, based on rational proof and based on the auditory proof of <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>> (There is nothing like unto Him). Thus, the Knowledge of Allah remains upon its original state of purity of Transcendence, rationally and legally, even though we describe Him with such attributes that suggest anthropomorphism (*tashbīh*). For His attributes, the Exalted, were not changed, so all of that is affirmed for Him while realizing <<لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْءٌ>>.

### [Numerous Proofs and the Doubt that affects one of them]

As for the ruling of little and much in this context, and the difference of opinion regarding impurity if the water is little: The fewness and abundance in purifying water (*al-mā’ al-ṭahūr*) refer to the proofs (الأدلة) possessed by the knower of Allah. If he possesses only one proof, and a doubt (*shubha*) arises in his knowledge of the Transcendence (تنزيه) of The Real in any respect, affecting his proof, its status as knowledge is removed, just as the status of that water as pure and purifying is removed. But if he possesses numerous proofs for a single proven point, the doubt is consumed within them. If the doubt impugns one of the proofs, he disregards it and relies on the rest of his proofs. Thus, this doubt does not affect his knowledge; it only affects a specific proof, not all of his proofs. This is the meaning of abundance in water whose ruling is not changed by impurity.

### [Knowledge is Impugned by Doubt at the Time of its Conception]

As for those who said to abandon the limit in this matter and that the water is spoiled: They consider the Oneness of the Essence (*aḥadiyyat al-'ayn*), not the Oneness of the proof. They say that knowledge is impugned by this doubt at the very moment of its conception, and time is subtle. He might die during that time without recalling the rest of the proofs due to the shortness of time, so the knowledge is spoiled in his view. There are many subsidiary issues in this chapter that do not need to be mentioned, and this amount is sufficient for the objective.

(Chapter on Water Mixed with a Pure Substance that is Usually Separable from it, when it Changes one of its Three Attributes)

As for water mixed with a pure substance that is usually separable from it, when it changes one of its three attributes: It is pure (*ṭāhir*) but not purifying (*muṭahhir*) according to everyone, except for some Imams, who hold that it is purifying unless the change resulted from cooking.

(Continuation: The Esoteric Ruling)

### [Knowledge of Allah through the Path of Thought is Pure but not Purifying]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) on this: The Knowledge of Allah (العلم بالله) derived from the intellect (العقل) through the path of thought (الفكر), when mixed with a legal attribute brought by the Law (الشرع), that Knowledge of Allah is pure in itself but not purifying, due to the attribute of anthropomorphism (*tashbīh*) it suggests. An example is their saying regarding the attribute of Allah's Speech (كلام الله) that it is "like a chain on a smooth stone," using the *kāf* (like) of description. The entire Law is manifest and acceptable in what it brings. The intellect could not detach itself from its proof in negating anthropomorphism, yet it submitted to the Law concerning what it brought without interpretation (*ta’wīl*). As for those who held that it is purifying based on its origin, unless it was cooked: they meant by "cooking" the natural matter (الأمر الطبيعي), which is that one does not take that attribute from the Lawgiver (الشارع), who reports from Allah, but rather takes it from his own understanding and investigation, drawing an analogy based on his own contingency and nature. Thus, it is pure but not purifying. Know this.

(Chapter on Water Used in Purification)

Scholars of the Sharia (علماء الشريعة) differed regarding water used in purification (الماء المستعمل) into three doctrines. Some say purification with it is not permissible. Some say purification with it is permissible, and this is what I hold. Some say purification with it is disliked (*karāha*), and dry ablution (*tayammum*) is not permissible if it is available. A fourth, rare opinion is that it is impure (*najis*).

(Continuation: The Esoteric Ruling on that)

### [Does the Use of Water Remove it from the Description of Absoluteness?]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) on this: Know that the reason for this difference is whether the name "absolute water" (*al-mā’ al-muṭlaq*) applies to that water or not. Those who held that it applies permitted purification with it. Those who held that its use affected its absoluteness did not permit it, or disliked it, depending on the strength of their conviction. As for those who deemed it impure, that is an unconsidered opinion, even though its proponent, Abu Yusuf, is considered authoritative.

### [Returning Unity to the Essence after using it in the Oneness of Acts]

Know that the Knowledge of the Unity of Allah (توحيد الله) is the purifying agent (*ṭahūr*) absolutely. If you use it in the Oneness of Acts (*aḥadiyyat al-af'āl*) and then, after this use, return it to the Unity of the Essence (توحيد الذات), the knowers of Allah (العلماء بالله) differed, mirroring the difference regarding used water. Some Gnostics (*'ārifīn*) said that The Real (الحق) does not accept this Unity from the perspective of His Essence (ذاته), so it should not be used thereafter in the Knowledge of the Essence. Other Gnostics said He accepts it, because we did not affirm an additional essence, and relations are not existent matters (أمر وجودي) that affect the Unity of the Essence. Thus, the Knowledge of Unity remains upon its original state of purity.

### [Absolute Unity is only proper for Allah]

As for those who said it is impure (*najis*): Absolute Unity (التوحيد المطلق) is only proper for Allah the Exalted. If you use this Unity in the oneness (*aḥadiyya*) of every individual, by which he is distinguished from others, it takes the ruling of the contingent cosmos (الكون الممكن). This is the meaning of impurity. Such Unity should not be attributed to Allah, because His distinction in His Oneness from His Creation is not based on commonality, as contingent beings are distinguished from one another by their specific attribute, which is their oneness.

(Chapter on the Purity of the Leftovers of Muslims and Grazing Livestock)

Scholars of the Law (علماء الشريعة) agreed on the purity of the leftovers (*su'r*) of Muslims and grazing livestock. They differed concerning everything else. Some held that the leftovers of every animal are pure, while others made exceptions, and the proponents of exceptions differed greatly.

(Continuation: The Esoteric Ruling on that)

### [Faith is Life, and Life is the Essence of Purity in the Living]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) on this: The leftover (*su'r*) of the believer and every animal is pure, for faith (الإيمان) and life (الحياة) are the very essence of purity (عين الطهارة) in the living being and the believer. Through life, the living being performs glorification (*tasbīḥ*) of Allah the Exalted, and through faith, the believer accepts without doubt what the Law (الشرع) brings, whether the intellect deems it impossible or not. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever knows himself knows his Lord."

What remains of knowledge for the servant after knowing himself—which is his leftover (*su'r*)—and every animal, is that it shares with the believing human in the indication (الدلالة). Thus, its leftover is similar to that remaining amount by which it knows its Lord.

### [Faith, because it is the Acceptance of The Real, grants an increase in the Knowledge of The Real]

As for those who differed regarding the exceptions: They did not consider the believer, nor the animal as an animal, nor the believer as a believer. The ruling proceeds according to what the one making the exception considered, and detailing this would be lengthy. We only stipulated the believer, rather than man alone, because faith (الإيمان) grants knowledge of Allah that is equal to what the animal and man grant, plus an increase that man does not attain merely by his humanity or animality, but by virtue of being a believer. For this reason, we said the leftover of the believer (*su'r al-mu'min*), for it is more complete in Gnosis (المعرفة).

(Chapter on Purification with Leftovers)

Scholars of the Law (علماء الشريعة) differed regarding purification with leftovers (*as'ār*) into five opinions. Some say they are pure absolutely, and this is what we hold. Some say it is not permissible for a man to purify himself with the leftover of a woman. Some say it is permissible for a man to purify himself with the leftover of a woman, provided she is not in a state of major ritual impurity (*junub*) or menstruation (*ḥā’iḍ*). Some say it is not permissible for either of them to purify themselves with the leftover of the other's purification water, but they may begin together. Some say it is not permissible at all. And some say it is permissible for a man to purify himself with the leftover of a woman, provided he has not been alone with her (*lam takhlu bihi*).

(Continuation: The Esoteric Ruling on that)

### [The Man exceeds the Woman by one Degree]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) on this: Know that the man exceeds the woman by one degree (درجة). If they are taken as a proof (دليل) for the Knowledge of Allah (العلم بالله) merely by virtue of being man and woman, then whoever sees that the increase in degree in the indication (الدلالة) grants superiority over one who lacks that degree, diminishes the knowledge by that amount. Those who did not permit purification with it said that the indication, by virtue of them being man and woman—meaning, actor (*fā'il*) and recipient (*munfa'il*)—points to a specific knowledge concerning the Deity, which is the knowledge of the one who affects it. This is found in every actor and recipient, so it is not permissible for such a thing to be found in the Knowledge of Allah, nor can the heart be purified from ignorance of Allah by it.

### [The Majority of Gnosis of Allah is that He is our Creator and the Creator of all Contingent Beings]

Those who permitted it said that the majority of Gnosis (المعرفة بالله) of Allah is that He is our Creator and the Creator of all contingent beings (الممكنات). Once our need for Him and His independence from us are established, we do not care about what knowledge of Him we missed. These are the two opinions regarding permissibility and non-permissibility.

### [Stopping at the Aspect of the Proof is an Increase in the Knowledge of the Proven]

By this consideration (*i'tibar*), we address the remaining categories, such as starting together. Starting together involves an increase in Gnosis (المعرفة), which is the absence of restriction by time, corresponding to the state of stopping at the aspect of the proof (وجه الدليل). This is also like considering their indication based on what they share, which is nothing but humanity.

### [Estrangement from the Locus of Femininity or Veiled Gnosis]

And like the purification of the woman with the man's leftover: this grants in the indication what the woman grants, plus an increase. And like the purification of the man with the woman's leftover, provided she is not *junub* (in major impurity): this corresponds to estrangement (التغرب) from the locus of femininity, which is the recipient (*munfa'il*). He has shared with the female who was recipient from him, for he is recipient from an existent cause (*mūjidah*). And provided she is not estranged from the locus of femininity by resembling the man, for that impugns her femininity; or provided she is not menstruating (*ḥā’iḍ*), which is an attribute that prevents intimate conversation (*munājāt*) with The Real in prayer. What is sought from the Knowledge of Allah is proximity (القربة), and the state of menstruation is distance from Allah in terms of intimate conversation with Him. Thus, Gnosis (المعرفة) with this attribute is a veiled gnosis (معرفة حجابية) derived from the Name The Distant.

### [The Servant has an Effect in the Presence of the Most High, the Most Holy]

As for the saying of the one who stipulated "provided he has not been alone with her": If he has not been alone with her, purification is permissible; if he has been alone with her, it is not permissible. Know that the knower of Allah (العالم بالله), while knowing that his essence (ذاته) is recipient in the existence of its entity from Allah, does not know that he pleases Allah or angers Him by his actions, since the obligation (*taklīf*) has occurred. If he does not know this, his gnosis is incomplete, and he has been alone with the gnosis (خلى بالمعرفة). This impugns the purity of that gnosis. If he discovers that he has an effect in that Presence (الجناب), such as His saying, <<أُجِيبُ دَعْوَةَ الدَّاعِ إِذَا دَعَانِ>> (I answer the call of the caller when he calls upon Me), then the supplication (*du'ā'*) from the supplicant grants the response in the essence of the One supplicated. There is no meaning for receptivity (*infa'āl*) except something like this. This is the reality of the saying, "provided he has not been alone with her."

(Chapter on Ablution with Date Nectar)

Scholars of the Sharia (علماء الشريعة) differed regarding ablution (*wuḍū’*) with date nectar (*nabīdh al-tamr*). Some permitted ablution with it, while the majority of scholars prohibited it. I hold the prohibition due to the lack of authenticity of the prophetic report they used as proof. Even if the hadith were authentic, his saying would not be an explicit text (*naṣṣ*) mandating ablution with it. For he, peace and blessings be upon him, said concerning it: "It contains good dates and purifying water (*mā’ ṭahūr*)." That is, the *nabīdh* combined dates and water, so it was called *nabīdh*, and the water was purifying before the mixture. Even if his saying "purifying drink (*sharāb ṭahūr*)" is authentic, it is not necessarily an explicit text for ablution with it, for it might be used to purify a garment from impurity (*najāsa*). Indeed, Allah only legislated for us dry ablution (*tayammum*) with dust specifically for purification for prayer when water is absent.

(Continuation: The Esoteric Ruling on that)

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) on this: It concerns the one whose Gnosis of Allah (معرفته بالله) relies on the legal proof (الدليل المشروع), which is a subsidiary indication derived from the rational proof (الدليل العقلي), which is the origin. The proponent of the legal proof lacks knowledge of how the Law (الشرع) is established as a proof in the Knowledge of the Deity, so his indication is weak. Even if he calls it "purifying water and good dates," that is due to the mixing of the two proofs. The imitator (*muqallid*) cannot separate the two proofs. Insofar as that mixture includes the rational proof, it is permissible to adopt it in the indication, thus permitting ablution with date nectar. Insofar as there is ignorance of its inclusion of the rational indication, it is not permissible to adopt it, and he lacks insight into the establishment of this subsidiary ruling. Thus, ablution with date nectar was not permitted, because he called it a drink (*sharāb*) and removed the name "water" from it. Understand this. <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the truth, and He guides to the way).

(Chapters on the Nullifiers of Ablution)

### [The Nullifier of Ablution is everything that impugns the Proofs]

The esoteric ruling (حكم ذلك في الباطن) on this—meaning the nullifier of ablution (*nāqiḍ al-wuḍū’*)—is everything that impugns the rational proofs (الأدلة العقلية) and the legal proofs (الأدلة الشرعية) in the Gnosis of Allah (المعرفة بالله). Regarding the rational proofs, this comes from arising doubts (*shubah*). Regarding the legal proofs, this comes from the weakness of the path leading to them, such as lack of trust in the narrators or strange texts (*gharā’ib al-mutūn*), for these weaken the report. Everything that removes you from the Knowledge of Allah, His Unity (توحيده), His Beautiful Names, and what is rationally obligatory, permissible, or impossible for Allah to possess—unless a continuously narrated report (*khabar mutawātir*) concerning it comes in the Book or the Sunna—all of that nullifies the purity of the heart (طهارة القلب) through the Gnosis of Allah, His Unity, and His Names. We shall mention them in detail, as they occurred in exoteric ablution, God willing.

(Chapter on the Nullification of Ablution by Impurities Exiting the Body)

### [The Disagreement of Scholars Concerning Sleep]

Scholars of the Sacred Law (علماء الشريعة) have differed concerning the nullification of ablution (الوضوء) by impurities exiting the body, holding three schools of thought (مذاهب). One group considered only the exiting substance (الخارج), regardless of where it exited or how it exited, though there is disagreement among them on specific details. Another group considered the two exits (المخرجين), the front and the back, regardless of what exited or how it exited, whether in health or sickness. A third group considered the exiting substance, the exits, and the manner of exit. This is the position I hold.

(Section on the Esoteric Ruling Regarding This)

### [The Utterance Exiting the Human Being via the Tongue Affects Faith]

As for the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) of these schools of thought concerning meanings, the one who considers only the exiting substance (الخارج) is the one who looks at the utterance (اللفظ) exiting the human being, for it is what affects the purity of his faith (إيمانه). For example, if he says in an oath, "I renounce Islam (برئت من الإسلام) if such and such is true," or "It was nothing but such and such." Even if he is truthful in his oath and does not break it, he does not return to Islam safely, as the Prophet (صلى الله عليه وسلم) said. This is also like the one who speaks a word that incurs Allah’s wrath (سخط الله) to make people laugh, not thinking it will reach the extent it does, causing him to fall into the Fire for seventy autumns. No consideration is given to whether the one from whom it exited was a believer or an unbeliever.

### [Hypocrisy: The Appearance of Faith on the Lips While Nothing of It is in the Heart]

The one who considers the two exits (المخرجين) is the hypocrite (المنافق) and the skeptic (المرتاب). Everything that exits from them does not benefit them in the Hereafter. The exiting substance may be impure, such as disbelief (الكفر) expressed through utterance, or it may be non-impure, such as faith (الإيمان). The case of the two exits is like that of the hypocrite and the skeptic, because the two exits are vile (خبيثان); what is not impure does not benefit them, such as the appearance of faith while nothing of it is in the heart. This is what Allah the Exalted says about them when they said: <<نُؤْمِنُ بِبَعْضٍ>> (We believe in some)—which is like the exiting of the pure, meaning that which is not impure—<<وَنَكْفُرُ بِبَعْضٍ>> (and disbelieve in some)—which is like the exiting of that which is impure. Thus, Allah the Exalted said concerning them: <<أُولئِكَ هُمُ الْكافِرُونَ حَقًّا>> (Those are the disbelievers in truth), and this affected their purity.

### [The One Who Knows the Truth Yet Denies It Out of Injustice and Arrogance]

As for the one who considers the exiting substance, the two exits, and the manner of exit (صفة الخروج), you have already understood the exiting substance and the two exits. What remains is only the manner of exit. The manner of exit concerning purity is like exiting in the state of sickness, such as the imitator in disbelief (المقلد في الكفر), or in the state of health, which is the one who knows the sound truth (العالم بالحق الصحيح) yet denies it and does not believe. Allah the Exalted said concerning those who knew the truth yet denied what guided them to it: <<وَجَحَدُوا بِها وَاسْتَيْقَنَتْها أَنْفُسُهُمْ>> (And they denied them, while their souls were convinced of them), then He mentioned the reason, saying: <<ظُلْماً وَعُلُوًّا فَانْظُرْ كَيْفَ كانَ عاقِبَةُ الْمُفْسِدِينَ>> (out of injustice and arrogance. So observe how was the end of the corrupters). End of the thirty-second part.

(Chapter on the Ruling of Sleep Regarding the Nullification of Ablution)

In the Name of Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful.

### [The Disagreement of Scholars Concerning Sleep]

Scholars have differed concerning sleep, holding three schools of thought. One group says that it is a ritual impurity (حدث), thus obligating ablution for both little and much of it. Another group says that it is not a ritual impurity, thus not obligating ablution unless one is certain of the impurity; the nullifier of ablution is the impurity, not the sleep. If one doubts the impurity, the doubt does not affect the purity, for the Sacred Law (الشرع) did not consider doubt in this instance. This is the position I hold. A third group differentiates between light, brief sleep, like a doze (السنة), which does not obligate ablution, and heavy, deep sleep (الكثير المستثقل), which does obligate ablution.

(Section on its Esoteric Ruling)

### [The Two States of the Heart That Remove Its Purity, Which is the Knowledge of Allah]

Know that the heart has a state of heedlessness (غفلة), which is the light sleep, and a state of death and sleep from wakefulness and attention to what Allah has obligated upon it, such as contemplation (النظر), inference (الاستدلال), remembrance (الذكر), and recollection (التذكر). These two states remove the heart’s purity (طهارة القلب), which is the Knowledge of Allah (العلم بالله). We have in this matter that which alerts the heedless and the spiritual traveler (السالك):

> O sleeper, how long this slumber?
> You are called, so awaken!
> The Deity would act on your behalf
> By what He called you to, had you slept with it.
> But your heart is heedless
> Of what called you, yet attentive
> To the world of creation (الكون) which destroys you
> Whenever you die with it.
> So look to yourself before your journey,
> If your provision is doubtful.

(Chapter on the Ruling Concerning Touching Women)

### [The Disagreement of Scholars Concerning Touching Women]

Scholars of the Sacred Law (علماء الشريعة) have differed concerning touching women (لمس النساء) with the hand or any other sensitive limb. One group says that if a man touches his wife without a barrier, or kisses her without a barrier, he must perform ablution, whether he felt pleasure or not (سواء التذ أو لم يلتذ). The proponent of this school of thought differed regarding the person touched (الملموس): sometimes equating them in the obligation of ablution, and sometimes differentiating between them. The proponent of this view also differentiated between touching unmarriageable kin (ذوات المحارم) and touching one's wife. Another group obligates ablution from touching if it is accompanied by pleasure (اللذة), and the adherents of this view have many details. A third group says that touching women does not nullify ablution. This is the position I hold. However, caution (الاحتياط) dictates that both the toucher and the touched perform ablution due to the disagreement on this issue.

(Section on the Esoteric Ruling of Touching)

### [If Desire Touches the Heart and the Heart Touches It, Ablution is Nullified]

As for the ruling of touching in the heart, women are an expression and metaphor (كناية) for desires (الشهوات). If desire touches the heart and the heart touches it, becoming entangled with it, and it comes between the heart and its necessary duty of observing Allah (مراقبة الله) in that desire, then its ablution is nullified. If it does not come between the heart and the observation of Allah in that desire, then the heart remains pure. For the purity of the heart is presence with Allah (الحضور مع الله). It does not matter whether the object of desire is forbidden (حرام) or permissible (حلال), provided one believes in the prohibition of the forbidden and the permissibility of the permissible; this does not affect its purity. However, if one believes in the prohibition of the permissible (which is explicitly stated as permissible) or the permissibility of the forbidden (which is explicitly stated as forbidden) due to desire, by looking to the opinion of an Imam who holds that view—while knowing that the Lawgiver (الشارع) confirmed the ruling of the independent jurist (المجتهد) and confirmed the acceptance of the heart’s action if it acts upon it—and before the desire, he knew that opinion but did not act upon it or hold it, but only reverted to it because the touch of desire affected his heart, then this affects his purity. In this case, ablution is obligatory without dispute among the People of Hearts (أهل القلوب). As for the exoteric ruling, we have a different view on this matter, and we have debated it with the scholars of external forms (علماء الرسوم).

(Chapter on Touching the Male Organ)

### [The Disagreement of Scholars Concerning Touching the Male Organ]

Scholars have differed concerning this, holding three schools of thought. One group says that ablution is not required, and this is the position I hold. Caution (الاحتياط) dictates ablution in every disputed matter, for caution is to move toward the point of consensus and agreement (الإجماع والاتفاق) whenever possible. Another group says ablution is required. A third group differentiated between touching it with pleasure or with the palm of the hand, and touching it with the back of the hand and without pleasure, and they detailed this.

(Section on the Esoteric Ruling of That)

### [The Cause for the Existence of Contingent Beings]

Know that Allah, exalted is He, made the cause for the existence of contingent beings (الكائنات الممكنات) only the Divine Will (الإرادة) and the Divine Command (الأمر الإلهي). For this reason, some have included the Will within the definition of the Command. Allah the Exalted said: <<إِنَّما قَوْلُنا لِشَيْ‏ءٍ إِذا أَرَدْناهُ أَنْ نَقُولَ لَهُ كُنْ>> (Indeed, Our word to a thing, when We intend it, is only that We say to it, "Be!"). He mentioned the Will and the Command, and did not mention a third meaning called Power (القدرة), so His saying <<وَاللهُ عَلى‏ كُلِّ شَيْ‏ءٍ قَدِيرٌ>> (And Allah is over all things competent) is understood as being the same as His saying "Be!" to things when He wills their formation.

### [Marriage is the Cause for the Manifestation of Generated Beings]

There is no doubt that the hand (اليد) is the locus of Power (القدرة). Since sexual union (النكاح) is the cause for the manifestation of generated beings (المولدات), whoever attributes power to it in bringing about the contingent entity that appears—which is touching the male organ with the hand—must either be heedless (غفل) of the Divine Power (الاقتدار الإلهي) in the command "Be!" or not be heedless. If he is heedless, his purity is nullified, as he attributed the existence of the child to the sexual union. If he is not heedless, he remains pure.

(Chapter on Ablution from What Fire Has Touched)

### [The Disagreement of the Companions Concerning Ablution from What Fire Has Touched]

The Companions of the Messenger of Allah (صلى الله عليه وسلم) differed concerning ablution from what fire has touched. Those after the first generation did not differ that this does not obligate ablution, except for camel meat (لحوم الإبل). I hold the view of performing ablution from camel meat as an act of devotion (تعبدا). This is an independent act of worship, even though his purity was not nullified by eating camel meat, so prayer with the previous ablution is permissible. However, he is disobedient if he does not perform ablution after eating camel meat.

### [The Obligation of Ablution from Camel Meat as an Act of Devotion]

This position is one that no one before us, to my knowledge, has held. If one intends by it the removal of an impediment, it is more cautious (أحوط). The Imams differed concerning ablution from camel meat: one group says it is obligatory, and another says it is not.

(Section on the Esoteric Ruling Regarding That)

### [Receiving Matters That Do Not Conform to Natural Purpose]

The fire (النار) that a person finds within himself, which cooks his liver, is due to matters that occur to him that do not conform to his natural purpose (الغرض الطبيعي). If he receives them with submission (التسليم) and contentment (الرضي), or with patience (الصبر) alongside Allah—just as Allah named Himself the Patient One (الصبور) because of His saying: <<إِنَّ الَّذِينَ يُؤْذُونَ اللهَ وَرَسُولَهُ>> (Indeed, those who abuse Allah and His Messenger) and yet He granted them respite and did not punish them—and the saying of the Messenger of Allah (صلى الله عليه وسلم): "No person is more patient with harm than Allah," due to His forbearance. If the servant is in this state, it does not affect his purity.

### [The Suggestion of Satan in the Human Heart]

If he is discontent (تسخط) and it affects him, especially regarding camel meat, which the Lawgiver (الشارع) called "devils" (شياطين), then that is the suggestion of Satan (لمة الشيطان) in the heart, and his purity is nullified, because the heart is the locus of the suggestion (اللمة). Just as one is purified from it by the suggestion of the Angel (لمة الملك). Camel meat is associated with the suggestion of Satan because Satan was created from <<مَارِجٍ مِنْ نَارٍ>> (a smokeless flame of fire), and the *marij* is the flame of fire. As we said, the Lawgiver called camels "devils" and forbade praying in their resting places, giving no reason other than their being devils—meaning the distant ones. Prayer, however, is a state of nearness and intimate conversation (مناجاة). Therefore, we considered the esoteric ruling (حكم الباطن) of ablution from camel meat and the nullification of purity by this. Even if his suggestion (لمته) was for good, he concealed within that good an evil that only the verifying scholar (العالم المحقق) who knows the Divine matters (الأمور الإلهية) and how they descend upon hearts can discern.

(Chapter on Laughter During Prayer as a Nullifier of Ablution)

### [The Human Being Whose States Vary]
