Furthermore, for the Gnostic, regarding the Attributes of His Essence [صفات ذاته] that The Real recites to him—which He does not inform about any of His creation—and regarding His speaking to His servant with this Quran, the purpose of that definition is only acceptance, and acceptance occurs only through the heart. If faith accepts it, he is not prevented from uttering it, for the Quran descended for our sake, and thus it is originated [محدث] in its coming and descent, but eternal [قديم] in that it is the Attribute of the Speaker, who is Allah.

[The Messenger was prevented by nothing from reciting the Quran except major ritual impurity]

The saying of the one who reported about the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that nothing prevented him from reciting the Quran except major ritual impurity, is not the saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, but the saying of the narrator, who was not with him at all times. The result of this is that the narrator means, "I did not hear him recite the Quran aloud [جهر به] while in a state of major ritual impurity." The reciter of the Quran is not obliged to recite aloud except where loudness is prescribed, such as teaching a student or in loud prayers. The prohibition concerning this has not been authentically reported from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and goodness should not be prevented.

(Chapter on the ruling concerning bloods)

[The three bloods specific to women]

Know that there are three bloods: menstrual blood [دم حيض], irregular bleeding [دم استحاضة], and post-natal bleeding [دم نفاس]. These are all specific to women, and the man has no ruling concerning them. The consideration [الاعتبار] in this should be for the soul [النفس], for femininity predominates in it, as Allah referred to it as *al-Nafs al-Lawwama* (the self-reproaching soul) and *al-Nafs al-Mutma'inna* (the tranquil soul), using the feminine form. The heart [القلب] and the spirit [الروح] have no share in these bloods.

[Lying is the menstruation of the souls]

We say that the People of the Path [أهل الطريق] among the early ones, and a group of others among the rational people who shared in the spiritual exercises [الرياضات] and struggles [المجاهدات] of the People of Allah, have agreed that lying [الكذب] is the menstruation of the souls [حيض النفوس]. Therefore, truthfulness [الصدق] is the purification of the soul from this menstruation.

[Consideration of menstrual blood]

Menstrual blood is that which exits in a state of soundness, while irregular bleeding is that which exits in a state of illness, for it exits due to a defect, and thus has a ruling. Its consideration is that the menstruation of the soul, which is lying, is, as we said, blood that exits in a state of soundness. This is lying against Allah, concerning which Allah Almighty says: <<ومن أَظْلَمُ مِمَّنِ افْتَرى‏ عَلَى الله كَذِباً أَوْ قالَ أُوحِيَ إِلَيَّ ولَمْ يُوحَ إِلَيْهِ شَيْءٌ>> (And who is more unjust than one who invents a lie about Allah or says, "It has been revealed to me," while nothing has been revealed to him). And the saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: "Whoever intentionally [متعمدا] lies about me, let him prepare his seat in the Fire." His saying "intentionally" is its exiting in a state of soundness.

[Consideration of irregular bleeding]

As for the person of doubt [صاحب الشبهة], no. The former lies and knows he is lying. The person of doubt says he is truthful in his own mind, but he is a liar in reality. As for the consideration of irregular bleeding, which is lying due to a defect [علة], it does not prevent prayer or intercourse. This indicates to you that it is not harmful [أذى], for menstruation is harm, and a man is harmed by intercourse during menstrual blood, but he is not harmed by it during irregular bleeding, even if it is due to illness. For this lying, even though it indicates falsehood, which is non-existence [العدم], it has a rank in Existence [الوجود], which is its utterance. The intention behind it was to repel harm from something that should be repelled by that lie, or to attract a lawful benefit in a situation where such a thing should appear and because of which it becomes an act of proximity to Allah, such that if he were truthful in that situation, it would be distance from Allah. Do you not see that the woman with irregular bleeding does not refrain from prayer despite the flow of her blood?

[Consideration of post-natal blood]

Post-natal blood [دم النفاس] is the very essence of menstrual blood. If it exceeds the duration of menstruation or departs from the attribute of menstrual blood, it exits the ruling of menstruation. The concern for post-natal blood is more significant than the concern for menstrual blood without childbirth. For Allah only held it back in the womb and then released it to lubricate the path for the child's exit, out of kindness to the mother, thereby easing the child's delivery for the woman. The child's exit is the pure generation [النشء الطاهر] that emerges upon the primordial nature [فطرة الله] and the affirmation of His Lordship [ربوبيته] that was theirs in the grasp of the particles [قبض الذر]. Thus, post-natal blood, with this intention, is a specific attribute, like an aid for the continuation of the remembrance of Allah by preserving the rememberer through a specific attribute. Post-natal blood has a time and duration in the Law, just as menstrual blood does, whereas irregular bleeding has no fixed duration.

(Chapter on the maximum and minimum days of menstruation and the minimum days of purity)

Scholars differed on this. Some said the maximum days of menstruation is fifteen days, some said ten days, and some said seventeen days. As for the minimum days of menstruation, some said there is no limit to its days, and this is the view I hold, for the minimum menstruation, in our view, is a single flow. Some said the minimum is a day and a night, and some said three days. As for the minimum days of purity, some said ten days, some said eight days, some said fifteen days, some said seventeen days, and some said an hour, and this is the view I hold. And there is no limit to its maximum duration.

(Connection) The consideration of this chapter is:

The duration of the soul's lying is the intention [النية], and it extends with the extension of what was intended until it is purified by repentance [التوبة] from that. Thus, there is no limit to its maximum or minimum duration. Likewise, the duration of purity has no single limit, for there is no limit to truthfulness [الصدق], except that the lawful situations judge it with praise or blame, though its origin is praise. Just as lying is judged by situations with praise or blame, though its origin is blame. Therefore, it is incumbent upon him to always be truthful, unless the state dictates otherwise. And it is incumbent upon him to always abandon lying, unless a certain state dictates it, which is lying due to a defect [العلة], thus resembling irregular bleeding.

(Chapter on the minimum and maximum duration of post-natal blood)

Scholars differed on this matter. Some said there is no limit to its minimum duration, and this is the view I hold. Some said its limit is twenty-five days, some said eleven days, and some said twenty days. As for its maximum duration, some said sixty days, some said seventeen days, some said forty days, and some said thirty days for a male and forty days for a female. The best approach is to refer to the states of women, for no Sunna has been established concerning it to which one can refer.

(Connection) Its consideration in the inner self [الباطن] is:

There is no temporal limit for the intention [النية], as we said in the consideration of menstrual blood, for menstrual blood is the very essence of post-natal blood, and we have considered it. For the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to the menstruating woman, "Have you given birth?" using this exact wording.

(Chapter on the blood seen by a pregnant woman)

Scholars differed on whether it is menstrual blood or irregular bleeding, and each scholar ruled according to the view he adopted.

(Connection) The consideration of its ruling in the inner self [الباطن] is:

The pregnant woman is the attribute of the soul when it is filled with a matter it finds, but then displays it incorrectly, which is lying. This may be due to a habit it has acquired, as some have said:

> A person only lies due to his baseness,
> Or a bad habit, or lack of manners.

As for his saying "due to his baseness," kings do not lie. And his saying "due to lack of manners" is based on the report that when a person tells a lie, the angel moves thirty miles away from him due to the stench of what he brought. Thus, the liar, in matters where lying is impermissible, has behaved improperly [أساء الأدب] toward the angel, for angels are harmed by what harms the children of Adam, and just as the human is harmed by stench, so too is the angel, due to the close resemblance between the nature of the angel and the nature of the human spirit.

(Chapter on yellow and turbid discharge: Is it menstruation or not?)

Scholars differed on whether yellow and turbid discharge is menstruation or not. Some said it is menstruation during the days of menstruation, some said it is only menstruation if it follows blood, and some said it is not menstruation, and this is the view I hold.

(Connection) Its consideration in the inner self [الباطن] is:

Lying due to doubt [شبهة] is not committed by one who intentionally lies. It is better to abandon it if one knows it is doubt, for it is only called doubt because it resembles The Real [الحق] from one perspective and falsehood [الباطل] from another. It is better to abandon such a thing unless it is accompanied by the repulsion of harm or the attainment of a religious or worldly benefit, unlike pure lying, which is for its own sake, and which no rational person commits at all. As for the lying that is in the position of irregular bleeding, the rectification of religion for the rectification of the world is considered in it.

(Chapter on what menstrual blood prohibits during its time)

Know that menstruation during its time prohibits prayer, fasting, intercourse, and circumambulation [الطواف].

(Connection) The consideration of this in the inner self [الباطن] is:

Lying in intimate conversation [المناجاة] is when you are outwardly in prayer but inwardly with other than Allah [غير الله], whether forbidden or not. Its consideration in fasting: Fasting is abstinence, and you have not restrained yourself from lying, just as the menstruating woman does not restrain herself from eating and drinking. This refers to the lying that is legally obligatory to commit and is praiseworthy. Its consideration in circumambulation [الطواف] around the House, which resembles the best of forms, the circle: This is lying without end, which is persistence in lying. Its consideration in intercourse [الجماع]: The believer's intention in intercourse is the existence of a child. If the premises are false, the result emerges from a corrupt origin. The result may sometimes be truthful, or it may be like its premises. The harm returns to the one performing intercourse. It means: during the time of lying, do not bring Allah Almighty to your mind, for that is bad manners [سوء أدب] toward Allah, lack of shame before Him, and audacity toward Him. How should a servant dare to be audacious toward his Master and not feel shame before Him, despite his knowledge and realization that He sees him? Allah Almighty said: <<أَ لَمْ يَعْلَمْ بِأَنَّ الله يَرى‏>> (Does he not know that Allah sees?).

(Chapter on interacting with the menstruating woman)

Scholars differed regarding the form of interacting with the menstruating woman. Some said that what is above the wrapper [الإزار] is permissible from the menstruating woman. Others said that only the place of the blood should be avoided, and this is the view I hold.

(Connection) Its consideration in the inner self [الباطن] is:

We said that menstruation is the lying of the souls. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was asked: "Does the believer commit fornication?" He said, "Yes." He was asked: "Does the believer drink wine?" He said, "Yes." He was asked: "Does the believer steal?" He said, "Yes." He was asked: "Does the believer lie?" He said, "No." So, if you see your soul as another soul doing what is improper, confirm that you must avoid lying against Allah and His Messenger among its actions. And whoever grazes around the sanctuary is likely to fall into it.

[Lying to people is the path to lying against Allah]

Whoever habituates himself to lying to people, nature gradually entices him until he lies against Allah, for nature steals him away. He Almighty says: <<ولَوْ تَقَوَّلَ عَلَيْنا بَعْضَ الْأَقاوِيلِ لَأَخَذْنا مِنْهُ بِالْيَمِينِ ثُمَّ لَقَطَعْنا مِنْهُ الْوَتِينَ>> (And if he had fabricated against Us some sayings, We would have seized him by the right hand, then We would have cut his aorta). Thus, He threatened His servants with the severest threat if they fabricated lies against Allah. This ruling applies to everyone who lies against Allah. It has been reported concerning one who lies in his dream that he will be tasked with tying two barley grains together with fire, corresponding to his fabrication of something that cannot properly be joined, and thus did not join in reality. Likewise, he will never be able to tie those two barley grains. This is an imposition of what is impossible to bear. Allah will only punish him on the Day of Resurrection through his own action, and not otherwise.

(Chapter on having intercourse with a menstruating woman before the ritual bath, after confirmed purity)

Allah Almighty said: <<ولا تَقْرَبُوهُنَّ حَتَّى يَطْهُرْنَ>> (And do not approach them until they purify themselves), with a *sukūn* on the *ṭāʾ* and a *ḍamma* on the *hāʾ* (yaṭhurna), lightly pronounced. It was also recited with a *fatḥa* on the *ṭāʾ* and *hāʾ* (yaṭṭaharna), heavily pronounced. Some said it is permissible based on the light reading, and others said it is impermissible based on the heavy reading, which is plausible. I hold the first view. Some said it is permissible if she becomes pure after the maximum duration of menstruation according to their school, and some said it is permissible if she washes her private part with water, and this is also the view I hold.

(Connection) Its consideration in the inner self [الباطن] is:

What the teacher imparts of knowledge into the soul of the student, if the student is recently characterized by the attribute of false claim [الدعوى الكاذبة] due to the recklessness of his soul, the teacher may impart to him knowledge related to formation [التكوين] that leads him to perform a single ritual bath with two intentions, so that he receives the reward twice. Even if he has not repented from that claim, but is not asserting it currently, his place is pure due to heedlessness [الغفلة] at that time. If the thought of abandoning that claim occurs to him, he is like the woman who washes her private part after seeing purity, even if she has not performed the ritual bath. If he repents from the claim by acting upon that thought, it is like the woman performing the ritual bath after purity.

(Chapter on one who has intercourse with his menstruating wife: Is expiation required?)

Some said there is no expiation [كفارة] upon him, and this is the view I hold. Others said expiation is required.

(Connection) Its consideration in the inner self [الباطن] is:

The knower who gives wisdom to those who are not worthy of it has undoubtedly wronged it. Whoever holds that there is expiation for this act, his expiation is to look for someone who is worthy of a beneficial religious science in the sight of Allah and is thirsty for it, and then hasten to teach him and quench the thirst of his longing, thus placing the knowledge in its proper place and with its people. This serves as expiation for his previous transgression. And whoever does not hold that there is expiation for it says that he should repent and seek Allah's forgiveness, and he is not obliged to seek out others to teach them by way of expiation.

(Chapter on the ruling concerning the purification of the woman with irregular bleeding)

Scholars of the Sacred Law differed on the ruling concerning the purification of the woman with irregular bleeding. Some said she is only required to perform one purification when she knows her menstruation has ended, and nothing else is required—neither ablution nor ritual bath—and her ruling is the same as that of a woman without irregular bleeding, and this is the view I hold. Another group said that even though she is only required to perform one purification, she must perform ablution for every prayer, and this is more cautious. Some said she must perform the ritual bath for every prayer. And some said she may combine two prayers with a single ritual bath.

(Connection) The consideration of the inner self [الباطن] in this is:

In our school, the woman with irregular bleeding, by virtue of being so, does not require purification. Likewise, the soul, if it lies for a lawful benefit that the Law made obligatory or permissible—nay, rather, he would be disobedient if he spoke the truth in that situation—then there is no repentance required for that lie. Just as irregular bleeding is not the essence of menstrual blood, even though they share the characteristic of being blood and the location, likewise, the lying whose permissibility is lawful is not the essence of the lying whose commission is forbidden, even though they share the characteristic of being a lie, which is informing about something contrary to reality. Whoever holds that repentance is required because the name "lie" truly applies to it, even if it is permissible or obligatory—like Habib al-Ajami in his story with Al-Hasan al-Basri when Al-Hajjaj sought him for execution, and the story is famous—he advocates repentance from it, just as he advocates the ritual bath for the woman with irregular bleeding, due to the shared name of menstruation, for *istihada* (irregular bleeding) is derived from *hayd* (menstruation).

(Chapter on having intercourse with the woman with irregular bleeding)

Scholars of the Sacred Law differed on this, holding three opinions: one permitting it, and this is the view I hold; one forbidding it; and one forbidding it unless the condition lasts for a long time.

(Connection) Its consideration in the inner self [الباطن] is:

It is not forbidden to teach someone from whom you know that he only lies for a lawful reason and a prescribed defect, for that does not impair his integrity; rather, it is an explicit confirmation of his integrity. Such behavior has occurred among the great and perfect Men.

(Chapters on dry ablution [Tayammum])

[The linguistic and legal meaning of dry ablution (Tayammum)]

*Tayammum* is the intention [القصد] toward pure earth, whatever that earth may be that is called earth—whether dust, sand, stone, or arsenic. If any of these things or their like separates from the earth, *tayammum* is not permissible with what has separated from the earth, except for dust specifically, due to the explicit text concerning it and concerning the earth, whether it has separated from the earth or not.

(Connection) Its consideration in the inner self [الباطن] is:

The intention toward the earth, by virtue of its being submissive [ذلول], is the intention toward absolute servitude [العبودية], because servitude is humility [الذلة], and worship [العبادة] derives from it. The servant's purification is only achieved by fulfilling what is incumbent upon the servant: humility, neediness [الافتقار], adherence to the rites and limits of his Master, and compliance with His commands. If the consideration departs from its being earth, then *tayammum* is only performed with dust from it, because we, whose children we are, were created from dust, and because of what remains in it of poverty and destitution, derived from the Arab saying, "May the man's hand be covered with dust" (meaning, may he become poor). Furthermore, dust is the lowest of the elements. Thus, the servant's adherence to his reality, based on his origin, is his purification from every ritual impurity [حدث] that removes him from this station. This only occurs when water is not found. And water is Knowledge [العلم], for by knowledge are the hearts given life, just as by water is the earth given life. It is as if this is the state of the follower [المقلد] in the knowledge of Allah. The follower, in our view concerning the knowledge of Allah, is the one who follows his intellect in its speculation regarding the knowledge of Allah from the perspective of thought. Just as when the person performing *tayammum* finds water or is able to use it, the *tayammum* is invalidated, likewise, when the Law [الشرع] brings a matter of Divine Knowledge [العلم الإلهي], the intellect's following of its own speculation regarding the knowledge of Allah in that matter is invalidated. Especially if the intellect's evidence does not agree with the Law's, the return is from the evidence of the intellect to the Law. Thus, he possesses both Law and intellect in this matter. Know that.

(Chapter on *Tayammum* being a substitute for ablution by consensus, and for the major ritual bath by dispute)

[Jurists' opinions on whether dry ablution (Tayammum) is a substitute for water or not]

Scholars of the Sacred Law agreed that *tayammum* is a substitute for minor purification [الطهارة الصغرى] but differed regarding major purification [الكبرى]. We do not say that it is a substitute for anything; rather, we say it is a prescribed purification [طهارة مشروعة] specific to conditions considered by the Law. For no ruling came from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, nor from the Noble Book, stating that *tayammum* is a substitute. Thus, there is no difference between *tayammum* and any prescribed purification. We said "prescribed" because it is not a linguistic purification. The details will follow in the sections of this chapter, God Almighty willing. Some said that this purification, meaning purification with dust, is a substitute for the major purification, and others said it is not a substitute for the major purification. The terms "minor" and "major" were attributed to purification due to the generality of purification in the ritual bath [الاغتسال] for the entire body, and its specificity to certain limbs in ablution [الوضوء]. The minor ritual impurity [الحدث الأصغر] is what necessitates ablution, and the major ritual impurity [الحدث الأكبر] is every impurity that necessitates the ritual bath.

(Connection) Its consideration in the inner self [الباطن] is:

Every ritual impurity [حدث] that impairs faith [الايمان] necessitates the ritual bath with water, which is the renewal of faith through Knowledge [العلم]. If he is one of the People of Speculation [أهل النظر] in rational proofs, and thus believes based on a rational proof, he is like the one who finds water and is able to use it. If he is not one of the People of Speculation in proofs, but is a follower [مقلد], purification is incumbent upon him through faith from that impurity that removed faith from him by the sword or by good conjecture. He is the one who performs *tayammum* with dust when water is lost or when unable to use water.

[Following (التقليد) in faith]

This applies according to the school of those who hold that *tayammum* is also a substitute for major purification, and thus permit *tayammum* for the person in a state of major ritual impurity [جنب]. As for the school of those who hold that the person in a state of major ritual impurity does not perform *tayammum*, such as Ibn Mas'ud and others, this is the one who does not accept following [التقليد] in faith, but insists on the necessity of knowing Allah, what is necessary for Him, what is possible, and what is impossible, through speculative proof [الدليل النظري]. A group of theologians [المتكلمين] held this view.

[Analogy (القياس) in legal rulings]

As for *tayammum* being a substitute for minor purification, this occurs when a ritual impurity impairs him in a specific legal matter, not in faith, due to the absence of an explicit text [نص] from the Book, the Sunna, or consensus [الإجماع] concerning it. Just as he was permitted *tayammum* as a substitute in this minor purification, he is permitted analogy [القياس] in the ruling of that matter, due to a common effective cause [علة جامعة] between this matter, for which there is no explicit ruling, and another matter whose ruling is explicitly stated in the Book, the Sunna, or consensus.

[Jurisprudence (الفقه) in religion is not analogy in rulings]

Our school, in saying that *tayammum* is not a substitute but a prescribed purification specific to a particular state, legislated by the One who legislated the use of water for this specific worship—which is Allah Almighty and His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him—holds that it is not a substitute. Rather, it is about extracting the ruling in that matter from a text found in the Book or the Sunna, such that the ruling in this matter falls under the general meaning of that text. This is jurisprudence [الفقه] in religion. Allah Almighty said: <<لِيَتَفَقَّهُوا في الدِّينِ>> (That they may gain understanding [tafaqqah] in the religion). And no analogy [قياس] is needed for this. For example, a man strikes his father with a stick or something similar. The People of Analogy said: We have no explicit text concerning this matter, but since Allah Almighty said: <<فَلا تَقُلْ لَهُما أُفٍّ ولا تَنْهَرْهُما>> (So do not say to them [your parents], "Uff," and do not repel them), we say that since the prohibition came concerning saying "Uff," which is minor, striking with a stick is more severe. Thus, the Lawgiver alerted us to the greater by mentioning the lesser, so analogy must be applied to it, for both saying "Uff" and striking with a stick share the common factor of harm. We therefore applied analogy to striking with a stick, which was not explicitly mentioned, based on saying "Uff," which was explicitly mentioned. We, however, say that we do not have the authority to impose rulings upon the Lawgiver concerning anything that may be obligated, especially in a case like this. Had nothing been revealed in the explicit text of the Law other than this, this analogy would not be binding upon us, nor would we adopt it or attach it to saying "Uff." Rather, we rule based on what was revealed, which is His Almighty saying: <<وبِالْوالِدَيْنِ إِحْساناً>> (And to parents, excellence [ihsān]). He made the address general, and from this general statement, we extract the ruling for everything that is not excellence. Striking with a stick is not part of the excellence commanded by the Law in our treatment of our parents. Thus, we only ruled by the explicit text and did not need analogy.

[The religion has been perfected, so no addition to it is permissible through analogy, just as no reduction from it is permissible through neglect]

For the religion has been perfected, and no addition to it is permissible, just as no reduction from it is permissible. Whoever strikes his father with a stick has not shown excellence [إحسان] to him. And whoever does not show excellence to his father has disobeyed what Allah commanded him to treat his parents with. Whoever rejects the words of his parents or does what displeases them, even if it is something permissible for him to abandon, has been undutiful to them. It is established that undutifulness to parents is among the major sins. For this reason, we said that purification with dust, which is *tayammum*, is not a substitute; rather, it is prescribed, just as water was prescribed. It has a specific description in practice, for it is clear that we only perform it on the face and the hands, whereas ablution and the ritual bath are not like that. A substitute ought to take the place of what it substitutes, but this has not taken the place of what it substitutes in action. And Allah <<يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (speaks the Truth, and He guides to the Way).

(Chapter on those for whom this purification is permissible)

[Dry ablution (Tayammum) for the sick person and the traveler if they cannot find water]

Scholars of the Sacred Law agreed that *tayammum* is permissible for the sick person and the traveler if they cannot find water. In our view, it is also permissible if they are unable to use water despite its presence due to an illness that they fear will worsen or cause death, based on the explicit text concerning this.

(Connection) The consideration in the inner self [الباطن] is:

The traveler [المسافر] is the person of speculation [صاحب النظر] in proof, for he travels with his thought through the stations of his premises and the method of their arrangement until the ruling in the desired matter is produced for him. The sick person [المريض] is the one whose nature does not allow for speculation in proofs, due to his known deficient nature and his inability to reach the intended goal through speculation. Rather, he must be restrained from speculation and commanded to believe through following [تقليدا].

[The follower (المقلد), the person of speculation (صاحب النظر), and the person of unveiling (صاحب الكشف)]

We have said previously that the follower [المقلد] in faith is like the one who performs *tayammum* with dust, because dust is not like water in purification, meaning cleanliness. However, we call it a purifier [طهور] legally—meaning dust specifically—unlike water, which I call a purifier both legally and rationally. The person of speculation [صاحب النظر], even if he first believes through following, desires to search for proofs and speculate upon what he believes, not out of doubt, so that he may attain knowledge through the proof he speculated upon, thereby moving from following [التقليد] to Knowledge [العلم]. Or he acts upon what he followed, and that action produces for him, through Allah, the ability to distinguish between The Real [الحق] and falsehood [الباطل] based on true insight [بصيرة صحيحة] that contains no following, which is the science of Unveiling [علم الكشف]. Allah Almighty said: <<يا أَيُّهَا الَّذِينَ آمَنُوا إِنْ تَتَّقُوا الله يَجْعَلْ لَكُمْ فُرْقاناً>> (O you who have believed, if you fear Allah, He will grant you a criterion [furqān]), which is exactly what we said. And He said: <<واتَّقُوا الله ويُعَلِّمُكُمُ الله>> (And fear Allah, and Allah teaches you). And He said: <<الرَّحْمنُ عَلَّمَ الْقُرْآنَ خَلَقَ الْإِنْسانَ عَلَّمَهُ الْبَيانَ>> (The Most Compassionate taught the Quran, created man, taught him clear expression). And He said: <<آتَيْناهُ رَحْمَةً من عِنْدِنا وعَلَّمْناهُ من لَدُنَّا عِلْماً>> (We gave him mercy from Ourselves and taught him knowledge from Our presence [ladunnā]).

[The journey of the intellect through its speculative thought and the journey of the practitioner through his action]

It has been reported that the scholars are the inheritors of the prophets.

Thus, they were named scholars, and the prophets did not bequeath a dinar or a dirham, but rather they bequeathed Knowledge (العلم).

The acquisition of Knowledge (العلم) through spiritual struggle (المجاهدة) and actions is also a journey (سفر). Just as the intellect travels through its theoretical contemplation in the World (العالم), the active practitioner travels through his action, and they meet in the result. The person of action has the advantage that he possesses insight (بصيرة) into what he knows, into which no doubt (شبهة) enters, whereas the person of contemplation is not free from doubt entering his proof. Therefore, the person of action is more deserving of the name 'scholar' than the person of contemplation. The discussion concerning what is permissible and what is not permissible regarding the journey (سفر) in the prayer of the traveler will come later in this book, if God Almighty wills.

(Chapter concerning the sick person who finds water but fears using it)

Scholars of the Sacred Law (الشريعة) differed concerning the sick person who finds water but fears using it. Some say that performing dry ablution (تيمم) is permissible for him—and this is what I hold—and he does not need to repeat the prayer. Others say he may not perform dry ablution despite the presence of water, whether he is sick or fearful. Others say that in both cases, he performs dry ablution but must repeat the prayer if he later finds water. Others say he performs dry ablution, and if he finds water before the time of the prayer expires, he performs ablution (وضوء) and repeats the prayer, but if he finds it after the time expires, he does not need to repeat it.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

The sick person (المريض) is he whose innate disposition (فطرته) does not allow for contemplation (النظر). This is a chronic illness, for although proofs (الأدلة) exist, he is feared to perish and leave the religion if he contemplates them due to his deficiency. We have seen a group of them leave the religion through contemplation because their innate disposition was defective, yet they claim that they possess sound Knowledge (علم صحيح) in this matter. They are as God said: <<وَهُمْ يَحْسَبُونَ أَنَّهُمْ يُحْسِنُونَ صُنْعاً>> (while they think that they are doing good work). Such a person, if he desires salvation, should adopt beliefs through imitation (تقليدا) just as he adopts legal rulings, and he should imitate the People of Hadith (أهل الحديث) and no others. This is the imitation of the Prophetic Hadith concerning God, based on God’s Knowledge (علم الله) of it, without specific interpretation (تأويل) through determined transcendence (تنزيه معين) or anthropomorphism (تشبيه). Most common people follow this path without realizing it. This, in the esoteric consideration, is the sick person who finds water but fears using it.

(Chapter concerning the resident who lacks water: what is his ruling?)

Some say that performing dry ablution is permissible for him—and this is what I hold—and others say that dry ablution is not permissible for the healthy resident if he lacks water.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

The resident (الحاضر) is he who remains upon the covenant (عقده) established for him by his parents and educators. Then he gains intellect, returns to himself, and becomes independent, considering whether he should remain upon that covenant or contemplate the proof (الدليل) until he knows The Real (الحق). Some say that what his parents or educators raised him upon is sufficient for him, and he should occupy himself with action, for contemplation (النظر) may lead him to confusion (الحيرة), and he is not safe from it. This is the one who permits dry ablution when water is lacking. We have already established that water is Knowledge (العلم) due to the shared life derived from it. For this resident, the proof (الدليل) is truly absent, as he sees no connection between God and His Creation (خلقه). Thus, Creation cannot serve as a sufficient proof for the Gnosis (معرفة) of the Divine Essence (ذات الحق). Therefore, his remaining upon imitation (تقليده) is preferable.

[Lack of Imitation (التقليد) in the Covenant and Lack of Contemplation (النظر) of the Proof]

Those who say dry ablution is not permissible even if water is lacking, say that he should not imitate, even if he does not contemplate the proof. For when faith mixes with the joy of the hearts, it becomes binding, and it is impossible for the heart to turn back from it. He does not know how it occurred or what it is like; it is necessary Knowledge (علم ضروري) for him. Thus, he has exited the ruling provided by imitation (التقليد), despite being neither a contemplator nor a possessor of proof. Most people follow this path in their beliefs. The lack of water for this resident is the lack of security for his soul against contemplation leading him into a doubt (شبهة) that would remove him from faith.

(Chapter concerning the one who finds water but is prevented from reaching it by fear of an enemy)

Scholars differed concerning one in this situation. Some say dry ablution is permissible for him—and this is what I hold—and others say he may not perform dry ablution.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

Fear of searching for the proof (الدليل) in order to contemplate it, which would lead him to the Knowledge (العلم) of the proven object (المدلول), is ignorance of the proof itself being a proof. Thus, one of two things is necessary: either he imitates someone regarding this being a proof for a specific matter, or he requires contemplation and thought regarding what he should take as a proof for the Gnosis of God (معرفة الله). If it is the former, let him remain upon his imitation (تقليده) in the Gnosis of God, and this is the one for whom dry ablution is permitted. And he who says dry ablution is not permissible says that this fear does not necessitate that he should not contemplate, so he must contemplate, absolutely.

(Chapter concerning the one who fears cold when using water)

Scholars differed concerning one in this situation. Some say dry ablution is permissible if he predominantly believes he will become sick if he uses the water. Others say dry ablution is not permissible. I hold the former opinion.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

The Sufi (الصوفي) is the son of his moment (ابن وقته). If his moment is health, he is not sick or severely sick, so he should not perform dry ablution, for illusion (الوهم) should not rule over Knowledge (العلم). The fear here may be an illusion, so he should not remain upon his imitation (تقليده), but must contemplate the proofs (الأدلة). And he who says dry ablution is not permissible, even if his moment is fear, is incorrect, for fear is a defect and an illness, so he must remain upon his imitation, absolutely.

(Chapter concerning the intention (النية) in the purification of dry ablution)

Scholars differed concerning the intention (النية) in the purification of dry ablution (تيمم). Some say it requires intention, and others say it does not. I hold the former opinion, for God said to us: <<وَمَا أُمِرُوا إِلَّا لِيَعْبُدُوا اللهَ مُخْلِصِينَ لَهُ الدِّينَ>> (And they were not commanded except to worship Allah, dedicating the religion sincerely to Him). Dry ablution is an act of worship (عبادة), and sincerity (الإخلاص) is the very essence of intention (النية).

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

If the covenant (العقد) is based on necessary Knowledge (علم ضروري) or on good opinion of a scholar or a parent, then it does not require intention (نية). The condition for intention is that it must be present in the person at the commencement of the action, accompanying the commencement. He whose belief is of this nature is not the agent of the action (صاحب فعل) such that he requires an intention, for the Will (إرادة) of The Real (الحق) Almighty, Who is the Creator of that action, is sufficient in this matter. He does not bring anything into existence except through the attachment of His Will, exalted is He, to its creation, and He does not bring it into being except through that Will. He Almighty said: <<إِنَّمَا قَوْلُنَا لِشَيْءٍ إِذَا أَرَدْنَاهُ أَن نَّقُولَ لَهُ كُنْ>> (Indeed, Our word to a thing when We intend it is only that We say to it, "Be"). This is an action He creates in the servant, so the ruling mentioned concerning it is necessary. Thus, the position of Zufar in this matter is more sound in the esoteric reality than the position of the majority, unless it is a disbeliever who embraced Islam. Such a person requires intention because he did not previously associate any act of drawing near (قربة) to God with this specific law called Islam, nor did he possess it before his conversion; rather, he considered it disbelief and entering into it as distancing oneself from God.

(Chapter concerning the one who does not find water: is seeking it a condition or not?)

Scholars differed concerning one in this situation. Some say seeking it is an absolute condition, and others say seeking it is not a condition. I hold the latter opinion.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

The imitator (المقلد) is not obliged to search for a proof (دليل), neither in subsidiary matters (الفروع) nor in fundamental matters (الأصل). What is incumbent upon the imitator, if he does not know the ruling concerning an incident, is to ask one who he knows possesses Knowledge (علم) among the People of Remembrance (أهل الذكر), so that he may give him a legal ruling (فتوى). God Almighty said: <<فَاسْأَلُوا أَهْلَ الذِّكْرِ إِن كُنتُمْ لَا تَعْلَمُونَ>> (So ask the People of Remembrance if you do not know). He who holds that seeking water is a condition is the one who demands from the one giving the ruling the proof for his legal opinion concerning the matter: whether it is from the Book or the Sunnah, or he demands that the scholar tell him, "This is the ruling of God or the ruling of His Messenger," in which case he adopts it. But if the scholar says, "This is my opinion," as the People of Opinion (أصحاب الرأي) say in their books, then it is forbidden for him to follow him in it, for God has only commanded him to worship according to what He legislated in the Book or the Sunnah, and God has not commanded anyone to worship according to the opinion of any person.

(Chapter concerning the condition of the commencement of the time for this purification)

The People of Knowledge (أهل العلم), may God be pleased with them, differed concerning the condition of the commencement of the time for this purification. Some hold it to be a condition—and this is what I hold—and others say this is not a condition for it.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

The Time (الوقت), according to us, is when the address of the Sacred Law (خطاب الشرع) is specifically attached to the legally responsible person (المكلف) concerning what he is charged with, outwardly and inwardly. Inwardly, it is a Divine Theophany (تجلي إلهي) that suddenly descends upon the heart, which is called the Assault (الهجوم) on the Path.

(Chapter concerning the limit of the hands (الأيدي) that God Almighty mentioned in this purification)

God says: <<فَتَيَمَّمُوا صَعِيداً طَيِّباً فَامْسَحُوا بِوُجُوهِكُمْ وَأَيْدِيكُم مِّنْهُ>> (Then perform dry ablution with clean earth and wipe your faces and your hands with some of it). The People of Knowledge, may God’s pleasure be upon them, differed concerning the limit of the hands (الأيدي) in this purification. Some say its limit is the same as in ablution (وضوء). Some say it is wiping the palms only. Some say that reaching the elbows is recommended (استحباب) while the palms are obligatory (فرض). Some say the obligatory limit is up to the shoulders. What I hold is that the minimum extent called a ‘hand’ (يد) in the Arabic language is obligatory, and whatever exceeds the minimum designation of the hand up to its limit is permissible for him, and is recommended (مستحب) according to me.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

Since dust (التراب) and earth (الأرض) are the origin of human creation, which realizes his servitude (عبوديته) and lowliness (ذلته), then the claim (الدعوى) of the Prophet’s saying concerning him—that he was created upon the Form (الصورة)—arose. This, according to us, is due to the preparedness (استعداده) upon which God created him, enabling him to assume the character of the Divine Names (الأسماء الإلهية) according to what his reality (حقيقته) dictates, for there is a difference of opinion concerning the meaning of the Form (الصورة) and the pronoun (الضمير) in the text. Thus, he became proud of this relation, exalted himself, and became arrogant.

So he was commanded to purify his soul from this arrogance by means of the earth and the dust, which is the reality of his servitude (عبوديته). Thus, he purifies himself by contemplating the origin of his creation—from what he was created—as God Almighty said concerning one whose characteristic this is, in the context of the remedy for this thought that caused arrogance: <<فَلْيَنظُرِ الْإِنسَانُ مِمَّ خُلِقَ>> (Let man observe from what he was created). And they are the sons: <<خُلِقَ مِن مَّاءٍ دَافِقٍ>> (He was created from an ejected fluid), which is the despised fluid. For among the things he claimed were power (الاقتدار) and giving (العطاء), yet he is inherently created upon incapacity (العجز) and stinginess (البخل). These characteristics are among the characteristics of the hands (الأيدي). So, when he made this claim and saw himself in apparent power, generosity, nobility, and giving, he was told: "Purify yourself from these characteristics by contemplating the weakness and stinginess upon which you were created." God Almighty says: <<وَمَن يُوقَ شُحَّ نَفْسِهِ>> (And whoever is protected from the stinginess of his soul), and He said: <<وَإِذَا مَسَّهُ الْخَيْرُ مَنُوعًا>> (And when good touches him, he is stingy). When he contemplates this origin, his soul is purified and cleansed of the claim.

(Chapter concerning the number of strikes on the clean earth (الصعيد) for the one performing dry ablution)

Scholars, may God be pleased with them, differed concerning the number of strikes on the clean earth (الصعيد) for the one performing dry ablution. Some say one, and others say two. Among those who said two, some said one strike for the face and one for the hands, and others said two strikes for the hands and two for the face. Our position is that one strike is sufficient, and there is no blame upon one who strikes twice. The hadith concerning the single strike is more established, so it is more beloved to me.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

The focus is on that by which this purification occurs. He who emphasizes the Unity of Acts (التوحيد في الأفعال) holds the single strike. He who emphasizes the wisdom of the secondary cause (السبب) established by God, and attributes the act to Him, exalted is He, while stripping the servant of agency—such as His saying: <<وَاللهُ خَلَقَكُمْ وَمَا تَعْمَلُونَ>> (And Allah created you and what you do)—thus affirming and negating, holds the two strikes. And he who sees this in every action holds two strikes for every limb. God knows best.

(Chapter concerning conveying the dust (التراب) to the limbs of the one performing dry ablution)

Scholars, may God be pleased with them, differed concerning this. Some say it is obligatory, and others say it is not obligatory, but rather it is obligatory to convey the hand to the limb of the one performing dry ablution after striking the earth with his hand or the dust. The apparent meaning suggests conveyance due to His saying, "with some of it" (منه).

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

If we hold that the purification of the soul is achieved through lowliness (الذلة), which is its origin, away from the pride (العزة) it claimed when it acquired it, then conveyance is not obligatory. For if we were to transfer lowliness to the locus of pride, the attainment of lowliness in that locus would be impossible, because what is already in the locus is stronger in repelling what comes to remove it. If they were to share the locus, two opposites would be combined, and neither would be more deserving of removal than the other.

[The Soul is Directed Towards the Presence of Pride (العز)]

The correct view in this matter is that the soul is directed towards the Presence of Pride (حضرة العز), and thus it acquired from the Light of Pride what led it to its claim. So it was told: "Turn your face towards your lowliness (ذلتك) and weakness from which you were created. If the lights of this pride remain upon you, then you are still yourself." It then occurred to the soul that those lights might remain upon it. When it turned its face towards its lowliness and weakness, the lights of pride inherently vanished from it, so it became dependent upon its Creator and submitted under His authority. This is why those who say that conveying the dust (التراب) to the limb of dry ablution is not obligatory hold their view. And those who say that the word *min* (من - from/some of) here denotes partiality, and that conveying the dust to the limb is necessary, say that the attribute (الصفة) does not subsist by itself, so it must have something to subsist in, and that is none other than the reality of the human being. Therefore, his attribute must be lowliness (الذلة), and only then is his purification valid. This is the position of those who hold that conveying the dust to the limb of dry ablution is obligatory.

(Chapter concerning what this purification is performed with)

Scholars differed concerning what is other than dust (التراب). Some say dry ablution is only permissible with pure dust. Some say it is permissible with everything that rises upon the surface of the earth, such as sand, pebbles, and dust. Some say the same as this, adding what is generated from the earth, such as lime, arsenic, gypsum, clay, and marble. Some stipulate that the dust must be on the surface of the earth. Some permit the dust on clothing or bricks. As for our position, dry ablution is permissible with everything on the earth to which the name 'earth' (الأرض) applies. If it separates from the earth, nothing of it is permissible except dust specifically.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

It has been established that the name 'earth' (الأرض) is removed from it by transference, and it is named arsenic, stone, sand, or dust (تراب). Since the text mentioned the name 'dust' (التراب) for dry ablution, and we found that this name accompanies it both when it is with the earth and when it separates from the earth, and we found no other substance like this, we made dry ablution obligatory with dust, whether it has separated from the earth or not. Legal rulings (الأحكام الشرعية) follow Names (الأسماء) and States (الأحوال), and the ruling transfers with the transference of the Name or the State.

(Chapter concerning the nullifier of this purification)

Scholars, may God be pleased with them, agreed that everything that nullifies ablution (وضوء) and ritual purification (طهر) also nullifies dry ablution. They differed concerning two matters. The first matter is when the person performing dry ablution intends a second obligatory prayer with the dry ablution by which he prayed another. Some say that the intention for the second prayer nullifies it, and others say it does not nullify it—and this is what I hold. However, the preferable course for me is that he must perform dry ablution again, because our position is that dry ablution is not a substitute (بدل) for ablution, but rather it is another purification specified by the Lawgiver under a specific condition, not in the manner of a substitute. We have already said that the ruling follows the State (الحال), and the ruling transfers with the transference of States (الأحوال) and Names (الأسماء).

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

Just as the Theophany (التجلي) is not repeated, this purification is not repeated. Rather, for every Theophany there is a purification, so for every prayer there is a dry ablution. But he who looks at the Theophany itself, insofar as it is a Theophany, and not insofar as it is a Theophany in a specific thing, says that one may pray as much as he wishes with a single dry ablution, just like one who performs ablution, with no difference. This is our position.

Until the glory of His Face appeared to the eye,
And to this point, it was nothing but He.

(Chapter concerning the finding of water by one whose state is dry ablution)

Some say that the finding of water nullifies it, and others say that the nullifier is the ritual impurity (الحدث).

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

We say: A proof (دليل) may arise for the imitator (المقلد) concerning a specific theological matter that contradicts what his imitation (تقليده) of the Sacred Law (الشرع) provided him. That proof does not remove him from his imitation; rather, what removes him from his imitation is the proof of the intellect (دليل العقل) by which the Sacred Law was established for him, not this specific proof. So, if the ritual impurity (الحدث) itself appears to him in what he believed through imitation concerning that matter, he knows from this that the Lawgiver did not intend this apparent meaning in this issue. The appearance of this sudden proof, which is equivalent to the finding of water, alerts him to this. This is the matter when you realize its truth.

(Chapter concerning whether everything performed with ablution is permissible with this purification)

Scholars, may God be pleased with them, differed as to whether more than one prayer is permissible with it. Some say it is permissible—and this is our position—though the preferable course for us is that it is not permissible. Others say it is not permissible, based on a branching difference of opinion concerning this.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

It has been established concerning the repetition of the Theophany (التجلي). The discussion concerning the fundamental issues of dry ablution, including the positions of the scholars, has concluded with brevity and conciseness. <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks The Truth (الحق), and He guides to the way).

(The first half of the first volume of *Al-Futuhat al-Makkiyya* is concluded, followed by the second half, the beginning of which is the Chapters on Purification from Impurity (النجس).)

The Meccan Revelations (*Al-Futuhat al-Makkiyya*) which God opened up for the Shaykh, the Imam, the Active Practitioner, the Firmly Rooted, the Perfect, the Seal of the Inheriting Saints (الأولياء الوارثين), the Isthmus of Isthmuses (برزخ البرازخ), Muhyi al-Haqq wa al-Din Abu Abdullah Muhammad ibn Ali, known as Ibn Arabi al-Hatimi al-Ta'i, may God sanctify his soul and illuminate his tomb. Amen. Remainder of the First Volume.

In the Name of God, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful.

(Chapters on Purification from Impurity (النجس))

[The Opinions of the Jurists (الفقهاء) on Purification from Impurity (النجس)]

Know that purification (الطهارة) is of two types: purification whose meaning is not rationally comprehensible (غير معقولة المعنى), which is purification from ritual impurity (الحدث) that prevents prayer; and purification from physical impurity (النجس), whose meaning is rationally comprehensible, for its meaning is cleanliness. Is it a condition for the validity of prayer, like the purification of the ritually impure person from ritual impurity, or is it not a condition? Some say that purification from physical impurity is an absolute obligation (فرض مطلق) but not a condition for the validity of prayer. Some say it is obligatory (واجبة), like purification from ritual impurity, which is a condition for the validity of prayer. Some say it is an emphasized Sunnah. Some say its removal is an obligation when remembered, but waived when forgotten.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

Know that purification (الطهارة) on our Path is of two types: purification whose meaning is not rationally comprehensible (غير معقولة المعنى), which is purification from ritual impurity (الحدث). Ritual impurity is a psychological description (وصف نفسي) of the servant, so how can a thing purify itself from its own reality (حقيقته)? For if it were purified from its reality, its essence (عينه) would be negated, and if its essence were negated, who would be legally responsible (مكلف) for worship? There would be nothing but God. Therefore, we said that purification from ritual impurity is not rationally comprehensible. The form of purification from ritual impurity, according to us, is that The Real (الحق) becomes your hearing, your sight, and your totality in all your acts of worship, thus affirming you and negating you. So you exist insofar as your Essence (ذاتك), and He exists insofar as your actions and perceptions.

[The Legal Responsibility (التكليف) belongs to the Servant, and the Act (الفعل) belongs to the Lord]

You are legally responsible (مكلف) insofar as the existence of your essence is the locus of the address, and He is the Agent acting through you insofar as you have no act, since ritual impurity (الحدث) has no effect on the essence of the act, but it has a ruling concerning the act. For what The Real (الحق) charged him with—movement and stillness—The Real does not perform except through the existence of the moving and the still, since if the servant were not existent, The Real would not be attached to movement and stillness, or be the locus of His effect upon Himself. Thus, the origination (حدوث) of the servant is necessary so that he may be the locus of the effect of The Real.

[The Origination (حدوث) of Creation (الخلق) and the Effect of The Real (الحق)]

Because he is originated (حدث), purification from it became obligatory upon the servant. For the prayer, which is the very essence of the apparent act in him, cannot be validly attributed to him because he has no effect; rather, he is merely a cause, insofar as his essence, for the manifestation of the Divine Effect in him. Thus, by purifying oneself from attributing the act to his origination (حدثه), the acts are validated as belonging to another, despite the existence of the essence, for the validity of the act which the Divine Essence (ذات الحق) does not accept.

[Purification from Impurities (النجاسات) is Purification through Noble Character (مكارم الأخلاق)]

Purification from physical impurity (النجس) is not like this, for physical impurity is the baseness of character (سفساف الأخلاق), and its meaning is rationally comprehensible, for it means cleanliness. Thus, purification from physical impurities (النجاسات) is purification through noble character (مكارم الأخلاق) and the removal of its baseness from the souls. It is the purification of the souls. Whether one intends worship (العبادة) by it or not, if one intends worship, it is grace upon grace and light upon light. If one does not intend it, it is merely grace, for noble character is sought for its own sake. Its highest rank is its use as worship through purification from physical impurities and the removal of impurities from the souls, which we said are character traits. Is it an obligation (فرض) according to us, or is it a condition for the validity of worship? God has made it an independent act of worship, sought for its own sake. Thus, it is like all other obligations: an obligation when remembered, waived when forgotten. Whenever one remembers it, it becomes obligatory, like the prescribed prayer. God Almighty said: <<أَقِمِ الصَّلَاةَ لِذِكْرِي>> (Establish the prayer for My remembrance). Next, we will mention the discussion concerning the rulings related to their specific entities.

(Chapter concerning the enumeration of the types of physical impurities (النجاسات))

Scholars, may God be pleased with them, agreed on four specific entities (أعيان) as impurities: the carcass (ميتة) of a land animal possessing blood (ذي الدم) that is not aquatic; the flesh of a pig, regardless of the cause of its death; the blood itself of a non-aquatic animal, whether separated from a living or dead creature, provided it is flowing (مسفوحا), meaning abundant; and the urine and feces of the son of Adam, except for a suckling infant. They differed concerning everything else.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration concerning the carcass (ميتة) of the land animal possessing blood)

Know that death (الموت) is of two types: original death (موت أصلي), which is not preceded by life in the one described as dead. This is His saying: <<كَيْفَ تَكْفُرُونَ بِاللَّهِ وَكُنتُمْ أَمْوَاتًا>> (How can you disbelieve in Allah when you were dead?). This is the original death, which is the non-existence (العدم) belonging to the contingent entity (الممكن), since its essence (العين) was known to God but had no existence in itself. Then He Almighty said: <<فَأَحْيَاكُمْ>> (Then He gave you life). And accidental death (موت عارض), which occurs to the living and removes its life. This is His saying: <<ثُمَّ يُمِيتُكُمْ>> (Then He will cause you to die).

[Accidental Death (الموت العارض) that occurs to the Living]

This accidental death is what is sought in this matter. Then He added another description, saying: "possessing blood" (ذي الدم), meaning the animal that has flowing spirit (روح سائل), that is, circulating throughout all its parts. He does not mean the one whose life is its very self, which belongs to all existing things. Then He added another description, saying: "that is not aquatic," meaning the land animal (الحيوان البري), that is, the one on land, not the sea animal, since the sea (البحر) is an expression for Knowledge (العلم). Thus, He says: "I do not mean the animal existing in God’s Knowledge (علم الله)," for disagreement occurs concerning that. Rather, I mean the animal whose essence (عينه) has appeared and whose life is by means of air. With all these conditions, its impurity (نجاسته) is established without disagreement. If one of these conditions is removed, it is not the intended subject by consensus.

[The Life of the Servant is Accidental, Not Essential (ذاتية)]

Since the life of the servant is accidental (عارضة) and not essential (ذاتية), he ought not to boast about it or make claims. When he made a claim and said "I," and was absent from the witnessing (شهود) of the One Who gave him life, accidental death occurred to him—meaning, "This is your origin"—returning him to his origin, but impure due to the claim and the forgetting of the One Who gave him life. Then we looked at the reason necessitating this claim. He said: "His being a land creature (بري)." We asked, "What is the meaning of his being a land creature?" He replied: "His life is from the air (الهواء)." So we knew that what was intended was caprice/desire (الهوى), as God Almighty said: <<وَنَهَى النَّفْسَ عَنِ الْهَوَى>> (And restrained the soul from [unlawful] desire). Thus, everyone who wavers between two desires is bound to perish, as our companion Abu Zayd Abd al-Rahman al-Fazazi, may God have mercy on him, said:

A sound desire and a sick air,
The soundness of my state is impossible with both.

He recited this to me in Tlemcen in the year 590 AH. Thus, every servant in whom these conditions are met, the scholars agree that he is impure (نجس).

[The Swine Characteristic: Or the Obsession with Filth]

As for the consideration of pig flesh: its flesh is the pathway of the bloody life, for flesh is congealed blood. The swine characteristic (الصفة الخنزيرية) is the obsession with filth (القاذورات) that souls find repulsive, and these are blameworthy character traits (مذام الأخلاق). If life departs from that flesh, it is impure (نجسا). This occurs when the possessor of the blameworthy character trait is absent from the ruling of the Sacred Law (حكم الشرع) concerning it, which is its spirit (روحه), making it a carcass (ميتة) in his regard.

[Forgoing Retribution for an Evil Deed is from Noble Character (مكارم الأخلاق)]

God Almighty said: <<وَجَزَاءُ سَيِّئَةٍ سَيِّئَةٌ مِّثْلُهَا>> (The recompense for an evil deed is an evil deed like it). He said "like it" and did not restrict it in a certain way, thus attaching it to blameworthy character traits. Then He said concerning one who does not do this: <<فَمَنْ عَفَا وَأَصْلَحَ>> (But whoever pardons and makes reconciliation). This draws attention to the fact that forgoing retribution for an evil deed is from noble character (مكارم الأخلاق). This is why we said [the pig is impure] regardless of what caused its life to depart, since ritual slaughter (التذكية) does not effect purification in it.

[The Recompense for an Evil Deed is an Evil Deed, so Pardon is Better]

The Messenger of God, may God’s prayers and peace be upon him, said concerning the man who sought retribution (القصاص) from the killer of his guardian: The Messenger of God asked him to pardon him or accept the blood money (الدية), but he refused. The Prophet said, "Take him," so he took him. When he turned away, the Messenger of God, may God’s prayers and peace be upon him, said, "Indeed, if he kills him, he will be like him," referring to His saying, exalted is He: <<وَجَزَاءُ سَيِّئَةٍ سَيِّئَةٌ مِّثْلُهَا>> (The recompense for an evil deed is an evil deed like it). That saying reached the man, so he returned to the Prophet, may God’s prayers and peace be upon him, and released the killer.

The issue of ugliness (القبح) and beauty (الحسن) is built upon this, and it is a major issue that people have delved into. This chapter is not the place to unveil the reality of that, although we have mentioned it elsewhere in this book.

[The Land Animal (الحيوان البري) is the Entity (العين) Existing for Itself, Not by Itself]

The third of the agreed-upon impurities is the blood itself of the land animal (الحيوان البري), when it separates from the living or the dead, and is abundant—meaning, excessive. We have informed you that the land animal is the entity (العين) existing for itself, not the one existing in God’s Knowledge (علم الله) like the sea animal, and that its life is by means of air, and that blood is the origin from whose heat the vapor emerges that constitutes the life of that animal, which is the animal spirit (الروح الحيواني). Since blood is the origin of this impurity, it is more deserving of the ruling of impurity than what is generated from it.

[The Impurity (نجاسة) of the Human Being When Negligence (الغفلة) is Abundant in Him]

What caused the servant to make the claim is the pride (العزة) upon which the human being was created, since he is the totality of the World (العالم) and corresponds absolutely to all existing things. When he became absent from the Divine Providence concerning this, and from the original death (الموت الأصلي) to which God drew attention in His saying: <<وَكُنتُمْ أَمْوَاتًا>> (when you were dead), and His saying, exalted is He: <<وَقَدْ خَلَقْتُكَ مِن قَبْلُ وَلَمْ تَكُ شَيْئًا>> (And I had created you before, when you were nothing), and His saying: <<لَمْ يَكُن شَيْئًا مَّذْكُورًا>> (He had not been a thing mentioned)—for this reason, scholars agreed upon his impurity (نجاسته) if it becomes excessive, meaning if negligence (الغفلة) concerning this station becomes abundant in him. If it does not become excessive, there is no agreement on this ruling.

[The Perfect Human (الإنسان الكامل) is the Deputy of The Real (الحق) on Earth and the Teacher of the Angel in Heaven]

The fourth is the urine and feces of the son of Adam. Its consideration: Know that whoever’s rank (مرتبته) is noble and whose station (منزلته) is high, his small faults are magnified, and whoever’s station is low and rank is base, his great faults are minimized. The human being is of noble station and high rank, the Deputy of The Real (نائب الحق) and the Teacher of the Angels (معلم الملائكة). Thus, whoever associates with him should be purified, and whoever mixes with him should be sanctified. When he became negligent of his reality (حقيقته), he occupied himself with his nature (طبيعته). Pure things—drinks and foods—accompanied him. He took their goodness by his nature, not by his reality, and expelled their foulness by his nature, not by his reality. Thus, their goodness became impure, which is blood, and their foulness became impure, which is urine and feces. It was more fitting that he should not acquire the foulness of odors, for he is from the World of Breaths (عالم الأنفاس). Thus, his impurity is due to his nature. This is also the case for every animal, except that the realities and spirits of animals are not in the high degree of honor and station like the reality of the human being. Thus, his slip was great, and they agreed without disagreement on his impurity from such things. They differed concerning the rest of the urines and feces of animals. Although all of it is from nature, whoever considered nature said all of it is impure. Whoever considered the station of honor and degradation said that the urine and feces of the human being are impure, and were not excused due to his great station, while excusing those animals below him. I have thus clarified for you the reason for the agreement and the disagreement. Praise be to God. <<وَاللهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks The Truth (الحق), and He guides to the way).

(Chapter concerning the carcass (ميتة) of the animal that has no blood and the carcass of the sea animal)

Scholars differed concerning these two carcasses. Some say they are pure—and this is what I hold. Some say the sea carcass is pure, but the land carcass that has no blood is impure, except for what is agreed upon to be pure because it is not truly a carcass, such as vinegar worms and what is generated in foods. Others say that both the land and sea carcasses are impure, except for what has no blood.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

We have already informed you concerning the consideration of blood in the preceding discussion of purification. He who holds the purity of the carcass of the animal that has no blood does so because it is free from the claim (الدعوى), for the claim occurs in the life generated from blood, not in the life belonging to all existing things by which they glorify God with His praise. That life is pure according to the origin because it is from God without a cause that screens it from God. And he who holds the purity of the sea carcass, even if it has blood, does so because it is in God’s Knowledge (علم الله), and there is no ruling upon things in God’s Knowledge. Rulings are only attached to them when they appear in their specific entities (أعيانها), which is their emergence from Knowledge into sensory Existence (الوجود الحسي). The rest of the differences of opinion concerning this matter are considered in a similar manner. The thirty-fourth section is concluded.

In the Name of God, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful.

(Chapter concerning the ruling on the parts of what is agreed upon to be a carcass (ميتة))

Scholars, may God be pleased with them, differed concerning the parts of what is agreed upon to be a carcass, although they agreed that the flesh, being a part of the carcass, is a carcass. We have already explained the consideration of flesh in the context of pig flesh. They differed concerning bones and hair. Some say both are a carcass, and others say neither is a carcass—and this is what I hold. Others say the bone is a carcass, but the hair is not a carcass.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

Since the death considered in this matter is the accidental death that removes the life that was in that locus, we looked at the definition of life. He who defined life as growth said both are a carcass. He who defined life as sensation said neither is a carcass. He who differentiated said that the bone senses, so it is a carcass, but the hair does not sense, so it is not a carcass. He who saw their growth through nourishment and their sensation through the animal spirit (الروح الحيواني) considered both a carcass, whether life was expressed as growth or as sensation. But he who saw their growth as being through their Lord, not through nourishment, and their perception of sensibles as being through their Lord, not through the senses, did not pay attention to the intermediary, due to his annihilation (فنائه) in the witnessing (شهود) of the Origin, Who is their Creator. If he saw that The Real (الحق) is his hearing and his sight, and the very essence of his sensation, it would not be valid for him to consider it a carcass at all, whether life was defined as growth or as sensation.

(Chapter concerning the utilization of carcass hides)

Some say that utilizing them is permissible absolutely, whether tanned or untanned. Others differentiate between being tanned and untanned. There is disagreement concerning their purity. Some say tanning (الدباغ) purifies them, and others say tanning does not purify them, but they may be used for dry things. Furthermore, those who hold that tanning purifies agreed that it purifies what ritual slaughter (الذكاة) affects—meaning, animals whose meat is permissible to eat—but they differed concerning what ritual slaughter does not affect. Some say tanning only purifies what ritual slaughter affects, and that tanning is a substitute (بدل) for ritual slaughter in conferring purity. Some say tanning works to purify the carcasses of all animals except the pig. Others say tanning purifies the carcasses of all animals, including the pig and others.

[The Position of the Shaykh al-Akbar concerning the Utilization of Carcass Hides and their Purification by Tanning]

What I hold and affirm is that the utilization of all carcass hides is permissible, and that tanning purifies all of them; I exclude nothing from the carcasses of animals.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

We have informed you of the definition of the carcass (ميتة). Utilization of its hide is not forbidden, and this is the application of the apparent meaning (الظاهر). He who adopts the apparent meaning in legal rulings without interpretation (تأويل) or deviation from the apparent ruling indicated by the wording has no impediment to this. There is no argument against us from those who claim that some wordings indicate anthropomorphism (التشبيه), for we say: "You have not adhered to the apparent meaning, for the apparent meaning did not bring anthropomorphism, because the word 'like' (المثل) and the *kāf* of description are not in the apparent meaning." That error in the matter only comes from interpretation. When a wording is of this nature, compared to an explicit wording that does not admit interpretation, it is, when paired with it, like the carcass compared to the living. Since we found no prohibition from the Lawgiver against utilization, we remained upon the origin, which is His saying, exalted is He: <<خَلَقَ لَكُم مَّا فِي الْأَرْضِ جَمِيعًا>> (He created for you all that is on the earth). He did not distinguish between pure and impure. Thus, we do not rule on its purity, even if we utilize it, unless it is tanned, in which case it is pure.

[The Ambiguous Wording is Ruled by its Apparent Meaning, but Not Affirmed Absolutely]

Its consideration is that when an ambiguous wording (اللفظ المحتمل) comes from the Lawgiver, we rule according to its apparent meaning, but we do not affirm absolutely that this is what is intended. If it happens that we find another text concerning that subject of the ruling which removes the ambiguity given by the first wording, that first wording is purified from that ambiguity. This second report acts for the wording like tanning acts for the hide. Thus, we combine its purity in itself—which is its definitive assignment by the second report to one of its possible meanings—with our utilization of it, just as we utilized it before it was pure, insofar as it is utilized, not insofar as it is utilized in a specific way. For that report might divert it from the apparent meaning in which we used it to another of its possible meanings. This is why we said: insofar as it is utilized, not insofar as it is utilized in a specific way, since others do not permit its utilization at all.

(Chapter concerning the blood of the sea animal and the small amount of blood of the land animal)

[The Sayings of the Jurists (الفقهاء) concerning the Blood of the Sea and Land Animals]

Scholars, may God be pleased with them, differed concerning the blood of the sea animal and the small amount of blood of the land animal. Some say fish blood is pure. Some say it is impure, based on the principle concerning blood. Some say that a small amount of blood and a large amount are the same in ruling. Some say that a small amount is excused.

[The Position of the Shaykh al-Akbar concerning Blood]

What I hold is that prohibition (التحريم) extends to all flowing blood (دم مسفوح) from any animal, and eating it is forbidden. As for its being an impurity (نجاسة), I do not rule on the impurity of forbidden things unless the Lawgiver explicitly states their impurity absolutely, or specifies the amount concerning which impurity is stated. The text commanding avoidance is not a text [of impurity] in every situation, so it requires a necessary contextual indicator. Not everything forbidden is impure, and even if we avoid it, we do not avoid it because of its impurity, for its being an impurity is a legal ruling (حكم شرعي), and it may not be repulsive or foul according to the intellect.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

The ruling upon a thing that it necessitates for itself does not require the existence of its essence (عينه) or the estimation of the existence of its essence. Thus, whether it is non-existent in essence or existent, the ruling upon it is the same, whether concerning its purity or lack of purity. Therefore, its being in God’s Knowledge (علم الله) or its being existent in its essence does not affect the ruling. Do you not see that the contingent entity (الممكن), whose existence was preferred over its non-existence, or whose non-existence was preferred over its existence by the determinant, has not departed from the ruling of contingency upon it? Contingency is necessary for it by its Essence (ذاته), just as impossibility is necessary for the impossible by its Essence, and just as necessity (الوجوب) is necessary for the Necessary Being (الواجب) by His Essence. Thus, the rational concept of necessity extends to the Necessary Being by Himself. Likewise, the ruling of the contingent and the impossible does not change, even if the Levels (المراتب) differ.

(Chapter concerning the ruling on the urines of all animals and the urine of the suckling human infant)

[The Sayings of the Scholars concerning Animal Urines]

The People of Knowledge (أهل العلم) differed concerning the urines and droppings of all animals, excluding the human being except for the urine of the suckling infant. Some say all of them are impure. Some say all of them are pure absolutely. Some say their ruling is the same as their flesh: whatever is lawful to eat, its urine and droppings are pure; whatever is forbidden to eat, its urine and droppings are impure; and whatever meat is disliked to eat, its urine and droppings are disliked.

(Connection: The Esoteric Consideration of this)

Purity (الطهارة) in things is the origin (أصل), and impurity (النجاسة) is an accidental matter (أمر عارض). We adhere to the origin unless that accidental matter occurs, and this is our position. The servant is pure in origin in his servitude (عبوديته) because he is created upon the innate disposition (الفطرة), which is the affirmation of servitude to the Lord, exalted is He. God Almighty said: <<وَإِذْ أَخَذَ رَبُّكَ مِن بَنِي آدَمَ مِن ظُهُورِهِمْ ذُرِّيَّتَهُمْ وَأَشْهَدَهُمْ عَلَىٰ أَنفُسِهِمْ أَلَسْتُ بِرَبِّكُمْ قَالُوا بَلَىٰ>> (And [mention] when your Lord took from the children of Adam—from their loins—their descendants and made them testify concerning themselves, [saying], "Am I not your Lord?" They said, "Yes.")

The Messenger of God, may God’s prayers and peace be upon him, said concerning this verse: When God created Adam, He took a handful from his back and extracted from it creatures like ants, and thus <<أَشْهَدَهُمْ عَلَىٰ أَنفُسِهِمْ>> (He made them testify concerning themselves).

[By His Name, The Holy (القدوس), He Created the Entire World (العالم)]
